standard.title: Transmission of IPv6 Packets over Frame Relay Networks

standardrecord.applicability:
This document specifies the frame format for transmission of IPv6 packets over Frame Relay networks, the method of forming IPv6 link- local addresses on Frame Relay links, and the mapping of the IPv6 addresses to Frame Relay addresses. It also specifies the content of the Source/Target link-layer address option used in Neighbor Discovery [ND] and Inverse Neighbor Discovery [IND] messages when those messages are transmitted over a Frame Relay link. It is part of a set of specifications that define such IPv6 mechanisms for Non Broadcast Multi Access (NBMA) media and a larger set that defines such mechanisms for specific link layers.
The information in this document applies to Frame Relay devices which serve as end stations (DTEs) on a public or private Frame Relay network (for example, provided by a common carrier or PTT.) Frame Relay end stations can be IPv6 hosts or routers. In this document they are referred to as nodes.
In a Frame Relay network, a number of virtual circuits form the connections between the attached stations (nodes). The resulting set of interconnected devices forms a private Frame Relay group which may be either fully interconnected with a complete "mesh" of virtual circuits, or only partially interconnected. In either case, each virtual circuit is uniquely identified at each Frame Relay interface (card) by a Data Link Connection Identifier (DLCI). In most circumstances, DLCIs have strictly local significance at each Frame Relay interface.

standard.title: Transmission of IPv6 Packets over IEEE 1394 Networks

standardrecord.applicability: This document describes the frame format for transmission of IPv6 packets and the method of forming IPv6 link-local addresses and statelessly autoconfigured addresses on IEEE1394 networks.

standard.title: IPv6 over Non-Broadcast Multiple Access (NBMA) networks

standardrecord.applicability:
This document describes a general architecture for IPv6 over NBMA networks. It forms the basis for subsidiary companion documents that describe details for various specific NBMA technologies (such as ATM or Frame Relay). The IPv6 over NBMA architecture allows conventional host-side operation of the IPv6 Neighbor Discovery protocol, while also supporting the establishment of 'shortcut' NBMA forwarding paths when dynamically signaled NBMA links are available. Operations over administratively configured Point to Point NBMA links are also described.
Dynamic NBMA shortcuts are achieved through the use of IPv6 Neighbor Discovery protocol operation within Logical Links, and inter-router NHRP for the discovery of off-Link NBMA destinations. Both flow-triggered and explicitly source-triggered shortcuts are supported.

standard.title: Transmission of IPv6 Packets over Token Ring Networks

standardrecord.applicability: This memo specifies the MTU and frame format for transmission of IPv6 packets on Token Ring networks. It also specifies the method of forming IPv6 link-local addresses on Token Ring networks and the content of the Source/Target Link-layer Address option used the Router Solicitation, Router Advertisement, Redirect, Neighbor Solicitation and Neighbor Advertisement messages when those messages are transmitted on a Token Ring network.

standardrecord.tag: IP over x.25 and ISDN Packet Mode

standard.title: Multiprotocol Interconnect on X.25 and ISDN in the Packet Mode

standardrecord.applicability: This document specifies the encapsulation of IP and other network layer protocols over X.25 networks, in accordance and alignment with ISO/IEC and CCITT standards. This document also specifies the Internet encapsulation for protocols, including IP, on the packet mode of the ISDN. It applies to the use of Internet protocols on the ISDN in the circuit mode only when the circuit is established as an end-to-end X.25 connection.

standard.title: IP Version 6 over PPP

standardrecord.applicability: This document defines the method for transmission of IP Version 6 packets over PPP links as well as the Network Control Protocol (NCP) for establishing and configuring the IPv6 over PPP. It also specifies the method of forming IPv6 link-local addresses on PPP links.

standardrecord.tag: Multi-protocol Encapsulation over AAL 5 over ATM

standard.title: Multiprotocol Encapsulation over ATM Adaptation Layer 5

standardrecord.applicability: This memo describes two encapsulations methods for carrying network interconnect traffic over AAL type 5 over ATM. The first method allows multiplexing of multiple protocols over a single ATM virtual connection whereas the second method assumes that each protocol is carried over a separate ATM virtual connection.

standard.title: The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP)

standardrecord.applicability: The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) provides a standard method for transporting multi-protocol datagrams over point-to-point links. This document defines the PPP organization and methodology, and the PPP encapsulation, together with an extensible option negotiation mechanism which is able to negotiate a rich assortment of configuration parameters and provides additional management functions. The PPP Link Control Protocol (LCP) is described in terms of this mechanism.

standard.title: PPP Chalange Handshake AuthenticationProtocol (CHAP)

standardrecord.applicability: This document defines a method for Authentication using PPP, which uses a random Challenge, with a cryptographically hashed Response which depends upon the Challenge and a secret key.

standard.title: PPP in HDLC-like Framing

standardrecord.applicability: The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) provides a standard method for transporting multi-protocol datagrams over point-to-point links. This document describes the use of HDLC-like framing for PPP encapsulated packets.

standard.title: The PPP Internet Control Protocol (IPCP)

standardrecord.applicability: The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) provides a standard method of encapsulating Network Layer protocol information over point-to-point links. PPP also defines an extensible Link Control Protocol, and proposes a family of Network Control Protocols (NCPs) for establishing and configuring different network-layer protocols. This document defines the NCP for establishing and configuring the Internet Protocol over PPP, and a method to negotiate and use Van Jacobson TCP/IP header compression with PPP.

standard.title: PPP LCP Extensions

standardrecord.applicability: The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) provides a standard method for transporting multi-protocol datagrams over point-to-point links. PPP defines an extensible Link Control Protocol (LCP) for establishing, configuring, and testing the data-link connection. This document defines several additional LCP features which have been suggested over the past few years.

standard.title: The PPP Multilink Protocol (MP)

standardrecord.applicability: This document proposes a method for splitting, recombining and sequencing datagrams across multiple logical data links. This work was originally motivated by the desire to exploit multiple bearer channels in ISDN, but is equally applicable to any situation in which multiple PPP links connect two systems, including async links. This is accomplished by means of new PPP [2] options and protocols.

standard.title: Nonstandard for transmission of IP datagrams over serial lines: SLIP

standardrecord.applicability: The TCP/IP protocol family runs over a variety of network media: IEEE 802.3 (ethernet) and 802.5 (token ring) LAN's, X.25 lines, satellite links, and serial lines. There are standard encapsulations for IP packets defined for many of these networks, but there is no standard for serial lines. SLIP, Serial Line IP, is a currently a de facto standard, commonly used for point-to-point serial connections running TCP/IP. It is not an Internet standard. Distribution of this memo is unlimited.

standardrecord.tag: Connection of IPv6 Domains via IPv4 Clouds

standard.title: Connection of IPv6 Domains via IPv4 Clouds

standardrecord.applicability:
This memo specifies an optional interim mechanism for IPv6 sites to communicate with each other over the IPv4 network without explicit tunnel setup, and for them to communicate with native IPv6 domains via relay routers. Effectively it treats the wide area IPv4 network as a unicast point-to-point link layer. The mechanism is intended as a start-up transition tool used during the period of co-existence of IPv4 and IPv6. It is not intended as a permanent solution.
The document defines a method for assigning an interim unique IPv6 address prefix to any site that currently has at least one globally unique IPv4 address, and specifies an encapsulation mechanism for transmitting IPv6 packets using such a prefix over the global IPv4 network.
The motivation for this method is to allow isolated IPv6 domains or hosts, attached to an IPv4 network which has no native IPv6 support, to communicate with other such IPv6 domains or hosts with minimal manual configuration, before they can obtain natuve IPv6 connectivity. It incidentally provides an interim globally unique IPv6 address prefix to any site with at least one globally unique IPv4 address, even if combined with an IPv4 Network Address Translator (NAT).

standard.title: Traditional Network Address Translation (NAT)

standardrecord.applicability: Basic Network Address Translation or Basic NAT is a method by which IP addresses are mapped from one group to another, transparent to end users. Network Address Port Translation, or NAPT is a method by which many network addresses and their TCP/UDP (Transmission Control Protocol/User Datagram Protocol) ports are translated into a single network address and its TCP/UDP ports. Together, these two operations, referred to as traditional NAT, provide a mechanism to connect a realm with private addresses to an external realm with globally unique registered addresses.

standard.title: Network Address Translation - Protocol Translation (NAT-PT)

standardrecord.applicability: This document specifies an IPv4-to-IPv6 transition mechanism, in addition to those already specified in RFC 2893:2000. This solution attempts to provide transparent routing, as defined in RFC 2663:1999 (NAT), to end-nodes in V6 realm trying to communicate with end-nodes in V4 realm and vice versa. This is achieved using a combination of Network Address Translation and Protocol Translation. The scheme described does not mandate dual-stacks (i.e., IPv4 as well as V6 protocol support) or special purpose routing requirements (such as requiring tunneling support) on end nodes. This scheme is based on a combination of address translation theme as described in RFC 2663:1999 (NAT) and V6/V4 protocol translation theme as described in RFC 2765:2000 (SIIT).

standard.title: Reverse Address and Port Translation (RAPT)

standardrecord.applicability: RAT or RAPT (Reverse Address and Port Translation) allows a host whose real IP address is changing from time to time to remain reachable as a server via a fixed home IP address. In principle, this should allow setting up servers on DHCP-run networks. While not a perfect mobility solution, RAPT together with upcoming protocols like DHCP-DDNS, it may end up becoming another useful tool in the network admin's arsenal.

standard.title: Router Renumbering for IPv6

standardrecord.applicability:
IPv6 Neighbor Discovery and Address Autoconfiguration conveniently make initial assignments of address prefixes to hosts. Aside from the problem of connection survival across a renumbering event, these two mechanisms also simplify the reconfiguration of hosts when the set of valid prefixes changes.
This document defines a mechanism called Router Renumbering ("RR") which allows address prefixes on routers to be configured and reconfigured almost as easily as the combination of Neighbor Discovery and Address Autoconfiguration works for hosts. It provides a means for a network manager to make updates to the prefixes used by and advertised by IPv6 routers throughout a site.

standard.title: Stateless IP/ICMP Translation Algorithm (SIIT)

standardrecord.applicability: This document specifies a transition mechanism algorithm in addition to the mechanisms already specified. The algorithm translates between IPv4 and IPv6 packet headers (including ICMP headers) in separate translator "boxes" in the network without requiring any per-connection state in those "boxes". This new algorithm can be used as part of a solution that allows IPv6 hosts, which do not have a permanently assigned IPv4 addresses, to communicate with IPv4-only hosts. The document neither specifies address assignment nor routing to and from the IPv6 hosts when they communicate with the IPv4-only hosts.

standardrecord.tag: Transition Mechanisms for IPv6 Hosts and Routers

standard.title: Transition Mechanisms for IPv6 Hosts and Routers

standardrecord.applicability: This document specifies IPv4 compatibility mechanisms that can be implemented by IPv6 hosts and routers. These mechanisms include providing complete implementations of both versions of the Internet Protocol (IPv4 and IPv6), and tunneling IPv6 packets over IPv4 routing infrastructures. They are designed to allow IPv6 nodes to maintain complete compatibility with IPv4, which should greatly simplify the deployment of IPv6 in the Internet, and facilitate the eventual transition of the entire Internet to IPv6.

standard.title: Generic Packet Tunneling in IPv6

standardrecord.applicability: This document defines the model and generic mechanisms for IPv6 encapsulation of Internet packets, such as IPv6 and IPv4. The model and mechanisms can be applied to other protocol packets as well, such as AppleTalk, IPX, CLNP, or others.

standardrecord.tag: Transmission of IPv6 over IPv4 Domains without Explicit Tunnels

standard.title: Transmission of IPv6 over IPv4 Domains without Explicit Tunnels

standardrecord.applicability:
This memo specifies the frame format for transmission of IPv6 packets and the method of forming IPv6 link-local addresses over IPv4 domains. It also specifies the content of the Source/Target Link-layer Address option used in the Router Solicitation, Router Advertisement, Neighbor Solicitation, and Neighbor Advertisement and Redirect messages, when those messages are transmitted on an IPv4 multicast network.
The motivation for this method is to allow isolated IPv6 hosts, located on a physical link which has no directly connected IPv6 router, to become fully functional IPv6 hosts by using an IPv4 domain that supports IPv4 multicast as their virtual local link. It uses IPv4 multicast as a "virtual Ethernet".

Requirements for Internet Hosts - Application and Support

standardrecord.applicability: This RFC is one of a pair that defines and discusses the requirements for Internet host software. This RFC covers the application and support protocols; its companion RFC 1122:1989 covers the communication protocol layers: link layer, IP layer, and transport layer.

standard.title: Requirements for Internet Hosts - Communication Layers

standardrecord.applicability: This is one RFC of a pair that defines and discusses the requirements for Internet host software. This RFC covers the communications protocol layers: link layer, IP layer, and transport layer; its companion RFC 1123:1989 covers the application and support protocols.

profilerecord.profilenote: Variable Length Subnet Masking (VLSM) (RFC 1812:1995, 2644:1999)

standard.title: Requirements for IP Version 4 Routers
Changing the Default for Directed Broadcasts in Routers

profilerecord.applicability: VLSM is, in concept, a simple extension of standard subnet masking. With VLSM, a number of subnet masks are defined for a single networkand used as needed to create different-size subnets. A class C network might, for example, be broken into subnets containing 16, 32 or 64 host addresses. To do this, the creation of individual subnet masks (with different lengths) is necessary.

standard.title: NATO Multi-channel Tactical Digital Gateway

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG is one of a series which, when taken together, specifies all the technical characteristics, parameters, and procedures necessary for two NATO digital tactical communications systems (networks) to interconnect and exchange traffic via a gateway.

standard.title: ISDN: ITU-T G, I Series

standardrecord.applicability: The ITU-T G and I Series contain the standards for digital narrowband (ISDN) telephone systems.

standardrecord.tag: ITU-T E, P, Q, V Series

standard.title: ITU-T E, P, Q, V Series

standardrecord.applicability: The ITU-T E, P, Q, V Series contain the standards for various analogue narrowband telephone systems.

standard.title: User Network Interface - UNI v4.0

standardrecord.applicability: UNI 4.0 adds a set of optional capabilities to the basic set embodied in UNI 3.0/3.1. Of considerable importance to IP--over--ATM efforts in the long run is support for ``Leaf--Initiated--Join'' of Point--To--Multipoint groups, the model for all current IP multicast efforts. At present, however, LIJ is not supported by native ATM routing protocols, nor used by such IP--over--ATM models as LANE and MPOA. Of more immediate interest, UNI 4.0 signaling provides for explicitly signaled QoS parameters, proxy signaling, ``anycast'' addressing for advertising well--known services, and Available Bit Rate (ABR) service. UNI 4.0 deployment has been gradual, with many vendors implementing only parts of the standard in current switches (ABR signaling and anycast in particular).

standard.title: User Network Interface - UNI v4.1

standardrecord.applicability: This new version of UNI Signalling specification, i.e. version 4.1, is comprised of: · af-sig-0061.000, ATM User-Network Interface (UNI) Signalling Specification, Version 4.0 (1996) · af-sig-0076.000, Addendum to UNI Signalling V4.0 for ABR parameter negotiation · af-cs-0107.000, Addressing Addendum to ATM User-Network Interface (UNI) Signalling Specification, Version 4.0 · Additional technical (see section 1.6) and editorial changes As a result, this specification supersedes the above three UNI signalling specifications.

standard.title: Private Network -Network Interface - PNNI v1

standardrecord.applicability: PNNI is a routing protocol that can logically represent groups of ATM switches as nodes. When nodes are added, the PNNI protocol recognizes and configures them into the logical routing topology of the intelligent network. PNNI is also a signaling protocol used during ATM connection establishment that sets up switched virtual circuit connections between nodes and provides networks with the intelligence to route around downed links.

standard.title: Private Network -Network Interface - PNNI v1.1

standardrecord.applicability:
This new version of the PNNI specification, i.e., version 1.1, is comprised of:
af-pnni-0055.000, Private Network Network Interface Specification Version 1.0 (March 1996)
af-pnni-0066.000, Private Network Network Interface Specification Version 1.0 Addendum (Soft PVC MIB) (September 1996)
af-pnni-0075.000, Addendum to PNNI V1.0 for ABR parameter negotiation (January 1997)
af-pnni-0081.000, PNNI v1.0 Errata and PICS (May 1997)
af-cs-0127.000, PNNI SPVC Addendum Version 1.0 (July 1999)
Any additional technical or editorial corrections or updates
Additional features (see Section 1.3 for more details)
An updated Mandatory and Optional Capabilities Table (Annex G of PNNI 1.0) listing all currently specified PNNI capabilities and referencing the associated PNNI addenda. As a result, this specification supersedes the above specifications.

standard.title: LAN Emulation over ATM - LANE v2.0

standardrecord.applicability: This document describes the LAN Emulation User Network Interface (LUNI v2). It supercedes the LAN Emulation over ATM Specificiation Version 1.0. LUNI v2 provides enhanced capabilities including LLC multiplexing for VCC sharing, support for ABR and other qualities of service through an expanded service interface, enhanced multicast support and support for ATM Forum Multiprotocol Over ATM. A second document describes the LAN Emulation Network Network Interface (LNNI) defining interfaces between the components of the LAN Emulation service.

standard.title: Standards for Data Forwarding between Tactical Data Systems employing Link-11/11B and Link-16

standardrecord.applicability: The purpose of this STANAG is to specify rules, protocols, and translations required between J series and M series messages. Data forwarding is the process of receiving data on one digital data link and outputting the data, using proper format and protocols, to another type of digital data link(s). In the process, a message(s) received on one link is translated to an appropriate message(s) on another link. Data forwarding is accomplished by the selected forwarding unit(s) simultaneously participating on more than one type of data link. The data that is forwarded is based on the data received and is not dependend upon the local system data of the data forwarding unit or its implementation of the received message or the forwarded message. Those data elements applicable within the messages are translated to the appropriate data elements in the corresponding messages. Within the data forwarding process, data management will be minimized. All systems that forward data must adhere to this STANAG. In the coure of implementing Link-16, it is recognized that some systems may use internal system translations (i.e., Link-16 to Link-11B) and some systems may transmit originated track data on more than one data link at the same time. Functionally, such systems are not data forwarders; however, these systems will adhere to the guidance in chapter 3 of this STANAG to ensure that the closest possible relationship of data elements and data element interpretation will be maintained among all users of the data.

standard.title: Technical Characteristics of the Multifunctional Information Distribution System (MIDS)

standardrecord.applicability:
MIDS is an advanced information distribution system that provides Communication, Navigation and Identification (CNI) capabilities in an integrated form for application to air, land and maritime tactical operations. These capabilities are provided in support of operational tasks through the ability of the system to:
Distribute encrypted information at a high data rate in Electromagnetic Countermeasures (ECM) environments.
Interconnect scattered sources of information such as surveillance, support, and intelligence on a continuing real time basis with selectable levels of connectivity among force elements such as weapon systems, weapon controllers and decision-making commanders.
Provide mobile surface and airborne force elements with a relative navigation capability within a common position reference grid.
Provide an identification capability through the dissemination of crypto-secure position, velocity, and identity information concerning both friendly and hostile force elements.

standard.title: Saturn

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the technical standards required to ensure interoperability of UHF radio equipment operating in the SATURN fast frequency hopping modes. It describes the fundamentals and the voice and data modes of the SATURN waveform. The waveform is fully capable of supporting all requirements in the Military Operational Requirement, listed in the STANAG.

profilerecord.profilenote: Tactical Communications Post 2000 (TACOMS), (Draft STANAGs 4637 - 4647):2005. It consists as a series of the following documents:

standard.title: TACOMS: Head STANAG
TACOMS: Element Performance
TACOMS: Interfaces
TACOMS: Lower Layer Specifications
TACOMS: ISDN Access Protocols
TACOMS: IP Access Protocols
TACOMS: Connection Oriented Network Protocols
TACOMS: Connectionless Network Protocols
TACOMS: Radio Protocols
TACOMS: Management Protocols
TACOMS: Gateway Protocols

profilerecord.applicability:
The aim of these NATO standardisation agreements (STANAGs) is to provide the standards for communications interoperability in the Land Combat Zone Post 2000.
The TACOMS standards have been designed to meet the TACOMS tactical communication system operational requirements in compliance with MC-337: NATO Post 2000 Military Operational Requirements for the Land Combat Zone.
They cover all communication subsystems that are to be deployed on a battlefield to fulfil communication interoperability required by the tactical operation:
LAS: Local Area Subsystem, responsible for the internal Headquarters communications,
WAS: Wide Area Subsystem, responsible for the long range communications,
MS: Mobile Subsystem, responsible for the communications required by the mobile users connected by radio equipment,
SMCS: System Management and Control Subsystem, responsible for the deployment and supervision tasks.
TACOMS Post 2000 was a standardisation initiative between 13 NATO Nations. Its aim is to improve interoperability between tactical land communication systems in future land based coalition operations.
The TACOMS approach is to provide a communications interoperability standard for network centric operations performed by NATO multi-national forces involved in a joint deployment. TACOMS is able to provide the communication interoperability standard for the NATO Response Force (NRF) initiative.
Legacy tactical networks deployed during the past 30 years are based on several different switching and transmission technologies, and provide different sets of native network services to users.
Interoperability with users in different networks (including legacy tactical) is currently achieved by means of gateways with an agreed minimum set of services.
This legacy gateway concept (as in STANAG 4206) provides interoperability with a very limited set of services. There is no user mobility, very limited bandwidth and limited packet data capability.
The TACOMS standards allow national systems to inter-operate with a maximum of coalition operational efficiency, while the individual national network elements maintain their value. The TACOMS standards also specify gateways to provide interoperability with external non-TACOMS compliant networks, such as civilian, military strategic and legacy tactical networks.
The standardisation in TACOMS fully specifies the interfaces between nations to enable interoperability, but does not mandate a technology to be used within the national systems.
The TACOMS concept is based on a Service Oriented Architecture and has been defined as follows:
An extensive set of end-to-end user and network services is defined for TACOMS.
Each nation chooses independently how and with what technology they will implement these user and network services internally in their network elements.
TACOMS standardised Interoperability Points (IOP) and User Terminal Access Points (UTAP) are provided at the edges of these elements, to interconnect them with other nations? network elements or user terminals.
The network elements are then defined in TACOMS with performance characteristics and transfer functions allowing multinational performance guarantees through Service Level Specifications (SLS) and their corresponding instances, the Service Level Agreements (SLA).
TACOMS External Network Access Points (ENAP) to provide connectivity to civilian and military networks.
The TACOMS standards define the interoperability requirements for a network consisting of interconnected national elements, in such a way that it appears to the users as one network, fulfilling all defined requirements for user services and their defined Quality of Service (QoS), capacity, mobility, robustness, security, etc.

profilerecord.profilenote: The following standards specifications are recommended:

standard.title: HDLC Frame Structure
HDLC Procedures
Multi-link Procedures
(X.25), X.25 LAP B DTE
HDLC Classes of Procedure
Address Resolution in Switched Environments
(X.212), Data Link Service Definition for OSI
Data Link Layer Standards

profilerecord.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring data link services. Note that the X.21 (synchronous digital interface) and X.21 bis (synchronous V-Series modem interface) Physical layer standards typically would be used to support ISO/IEC 7776 (X.25 LAP B).

standard.title: ISDN Basic user-network interface - Layer 1 specification
ISDN Primary rate user-network interface - Layer 1 specification
ETSI Basic interface specification
ETSI Primary interface specification
DSS1 ISDN User interface network Data Link layer
ISDN User interface network Data Link layer specification Link Access Protocol D (LAPD)
X.25 over ISDN B or D channels
Numbering standard for ISDN era
ISDN-PCI, ETSI ISDN Program Control Interface (ISDN API)
Common ISDN API (CAPI) v2

profilerecord.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring digital, circuit switched services. The ISDN standards cover a telecommunications area analogous to the existing voice telephony network but operating digital signalling and capable of much higher data rates. ISDN circuits offer the user the ability to dial another ISDN user (using ITU-T E.164 ISDN numbering standard) and to use the enhanced data capacity in very flexible ways. ISDN is best viewed as a data pipeline which, once a connection has been established between two users, may operate a variety of protocols and carry all types of data, including voice and image. Although ISDN was originally implemented in different ways in Europe there is now a standard, Euro-ISDN, created by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI), to which all European nations have subscribed and which now covers most of the population of Europe. The Basic user-network interface offers the user two 64kbps 'B' or Bearer channels. These may be used individually for conventional data communications or may be grouped together to give an aggregate data capacity of 128kbps for applications like restricted video. There is also a 16kbps 'D' channel which the ISDN network uses to control the operation of the 'B' channels. Euro-ISDN specifies the use of 64kbps circuit switching or 3.1kHz speech over 'B' channels but will progress to cover X.31 (X.25 over ISDN) over 'B' and 'D' channels, along with 7 KHz speech. In fact, some European PTTs are already offering an X.25 packet switching service to ISDN subscribers based on the 'D' channel. The Primary rate user-interface offers the subscriber thirty 64kbps 'B' channels and, as with the Basic interface, these may be operated singly or grouped together to service users at the termination point. The Primary rate also features a 64kbps 'D' control channel. Corporate subscribers with more than just a small number of users will be more likely to use a Primary rate interface. The thirty 'B' channels can aggregate up to a 2.048Mbps connection.

profilerecord.profilenote: The following standards specifications are recommended:

standard.title: Vocabulary of Terms for broadband aspects of ISDN
Broadband aspects of ISDN

profilerecord.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring high capacity, digital, circuit-switched services. Broadband ISDN extends the narrow band ISDN concept of end-to-end user data transfer into the very high capacities offered by fibre optics. Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM), with its concept of fast switching of small cells, has become the choice of implementation of B-ISDN.

profilerecord.profilenote: The following standards specifications are recommended:

standard.title: B-ISDN ATM Layer Specification
B-ISDN Adaption Layer (AAL) Specification

profilerecord.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring fast packet switching services. ATM is a cell relay switching technique similar to Frame Relay. ATM is intended for use with Broadband-ISDN (B-ISDN) and will eventually offer transmission speeds of between 155 Mbits/s and 2.4 Gbits/s over such emergent technologies as Synchronous Digital Hierarchy (SDH) in Europe and Synchronous Optical Network (SONET) in the USA. ATM is built on the use of a standard sized packet, or cell, of 53 bytes. The user traffic volume offered by this technology will make the simultaneous transmission of data, voice and video a practical proposition and will probably obsolete much of today's technology in due course.

standard.title: Logical Link Control (LLC)

standardrecord.applicability: The above standard is applicable to systems requiring LAN services. LLC provides a common 'upper half' of the Data Link layer, operating over diverse, specific LAN technologies.

standard.title: Carrier Sense Multiple Access/Collision Detect (CSMA/CD)

standardrecord.applicability: The above standard is applicable to systems requiring LAN services. CSMA/CD has seen wide adoption throughout the world, especially in the form of Ethernet. The most common form is a 10Mbps star topology (10BaseT, twisted pair), although a 100Mbps variant (Fast Ethernet, or 100BaseT) is about to see increased use. Ethernet users simply put traffic on the network and if traffic clashes (collides) with other users' traffic then users will back off and wait for a random period before retrying.

standard.title: Token Ring

standardrecord.applicability: The above standard is applicable to systems requiring LAN services. Token Ring has similarities with Token Bus but in this case the LAN topology is functionally a ring on which users reside. (Functionally a ring, but in reality star-wired from a controller.) A token continuously travels the ring and is grabbed by a user wishing to transmit. The data having been transmitted between sender and receiver a fresh token is placed on the ring.

standard.title: Wireless LAN

standardrecord.applicability: The purpose of this standard is to provide wireless connectivity to automatic machinery, equipment, or stations that require rapid deployment, which may be portable or hand-hold, or which may be mounted on moving vehicles within a local area. This standard also offers regulatory bodies a means of standardisingf access to one or more frequency bands for the purpose of local area communication.

standard.title: 100VG-AnyLAN

standardrecord.applicability: The above standard is applicable to systems requiring high-speed LAN services. 100VG-AnyLAN is a recent LAN standard based on deterministic principles. It can use a frame size up to 4096 bytes and is compatible with a wide choice of existing cabling standards. 100BaseT Ethernet probably offers superior throughput but 100VG-AnyLAN is more flexible and can handle time-critical traffic better.

standard.title: Conformance Testing Methodology and Framework

standardrecord.applicability: This publication covers spectrum management in the full range and intensity of combined military operations to include peacetime, humanitarian operations, and warfare. It covers management of all equipment operating within the electromagnetic spectrum in the frequency range 9kHz to 400GHz. It does not cover specific alliance or national arrangements, which may be covered by either individual supplements to this publication, or by separate publications.

standard.title: ACP 190 (B) Expanding Procedures

standardrecord.applicability: This publication addresses expanding procedures for equipment certification

standard.title: ACP 190 (B) Classified Frequencies

standardrecord.applicability: This publication addresses classified frequencies for use by NATO and coalition forces

standard.title: SMADEF XML Documentation Rel.1.2.3

standardrecord.applicability: The objective of this document is to define the Concept of Operations (CONOPS) and data elements for the exchange of spectrum management related data, including but not limited to Locations, Spectrum Supportability and the associated Host Nation Replies, Allotments, temporary or permanent frequency Proposals and Assignments, Interference Reports, Joint Restricted Frequency Lists (JRFL), Communications Electronics Operating Instructions (CEOI), and Hazards of Electromagnetic Radiations to Ordinance (HERO). The CONOPS includes the purpose of Spectrum Management Allied Data Exchange Format - eXtensible Markup Language (SMADEF-XML), the business needs that SMADEF-XML satisfies, the basic concepts behind SMADEF-XML, and finally its characteristics and behaviour from the user point of view.

standard.title: 1000Base-T

standardrecord.applicability: 1000Base-T provides half-duplex (CSMA/CD) and full-duplex 1000 Mb/s Ethernet service over Category 5 links as defined by ANSI/TIA/EIA-568-A. Topology rules for 1000Base-T are the same as those used for 100Base-T (100VG-AnyLAN). Category 5 link length are limited to 100 meters by the ANSI/TIA/EIA-568-A cabling standard. Only one CSMA/CD repeater will be allowed in a collision domain.

profilerecord.profilenote: The following standards specifications are recommended:

standard.title: FDDI Part 1: Token Ring Physical Layer Protocol (PHY)
FDDI Part 2: Token Rinf Media Access Control (MAC)
FDDI Part 3: Physical Layer Medium Dependent (PMD)
FDDI Part 4: Single Mode Fibre Physical Layer Medium Dependent (SMF-PMD)

FDDI Part 26: Media Access Control Conformance Testing (MAC-ATS)

profilerecord.applicability: The above standard is applicable to systems requiring high-speed LAN services. FDDI provides a high bandwidth (100 Mbps) general-purpose interconnection among computers and peripheral equipment using optical fibre as the transmission medium in a dual-ring configuration. FDDI establishes the connection among many stations distributed over distances of several km in extent. FDDI is used for high capacity trunk links and is now increasingly being used to connect small systems on LANs.

standard.title: Interface between Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) and Data Circuit-terminating Equipment (DCE) for terminals operating in the packet mode and connected to public data networks by dedicated circuit

standardrecord.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring connection-oriented network services.

profilerecord.profilenote: The following standards specifications are recommended:

standard.title: Error-correcting procedures for DCEs using asynchronous-to-synchronous conversion
Modem for PSTN at 56000 bit/s (downstream) and 33600 bit/s (upstream)

profilerecord.applicability: The above standards are applicable to systems requiring connection-oriented network services.

standard.title: Interface Between Data Terminal Equipment and Data Communications Equipment Employing Serial Binary Data Interchange (identical with ITU-T V.24/V.28:1991)

standardrecord.applicability:
RS-232 has been around as a standard for decades is an electrical interface between Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) and Data Circuit-Terminating Equipment (DCE) such as modems or DSUs. It appears under different incarnations such as RS-232C, RS-232D, V.24, V.28 or V.10 but essentially all these interfaces are interoperable. RS-232 is used for asynchronous data transfer as well as synchronous links such as SDLC, HDLC, Frame Relay and X.25.
In its simplest form, the RS-232-C interface consist of only two wires-one to carry data, plus a "circuit common". The circuit common is the absolute voltage reference for all the interface circuitry, the point in the circuit from which all voltages are measured.
A typical DTE device is an ordinary video terminal with a keyboard and a video display. Data on pin 2 of the DTE is transmitted, while the same data on pin 2 of a DCE (modem) is received data.

standard.title: RS-422/423,Serial binary data interchange between a DTE and a DCE:2005

standardrecord.applicability:
The limitations of RS-232 are largely eliminated by the balanced line interface.
The RS-422 protocol greatly expands the practical possibilities of the serial bus. It provides a mechanism by which serial data can be transmitted over great distances (to 4,000 feet) and at very high speeds (to10 Mbps). This is accomplished by splitting each signal across two separate wires in opposite states, one inverted and one not inverted. The difference in voltage between the two lines is compared by the receiver to determine the logical state of the signal. This wire configuration, called differential data transmission or balanced transmission, is well suited to noisy environments. With RS-232 communication, which is unbalanced transmission and uses only one wire, signal degradation can take place if there is a difference in ground potential between the transmitting and receiving ends of the cable. With balanced transmission, this potential difference will affect both wires equally, and thus not effect their inverse relationship. Twisted pairs of wire, which ensure that neither line is permanently closer to a noise source than the other, are often used to best equalize influences on the two lines. Errors can be caused by high noise levels affecting one side of the receiver to a different extent than the other. To combat this, each receiver is generally grounded.
RS-422 supports multipoint connections whereas RS-423 supports only point-to-point connections.

standard.title: TIA-530-A,Serial binary data interchange between a DTE and a DCE, EIA/TIA:2004

standardrecord.applicability: RS-530 - Supersedes RS-449 and complements RS-232. Based on a 25-pin connection, it works in conjunction with either electrical interface RS-422 (balanced electrical circuits) or RS-423 (unbalanced electrical circuits). RS-530 defines the mechanical/electrical interfaces between DTEs and DCEs that transmit serial binary data, whether synchronous or asynchronous. RS-530 provides a means for taking advantage of higher data rates with the same mechanical connector used for RS-232. However, RS-530 and RS-232 are not compatible!

standard.title: Generic Specification for Optical Waveguide Fibers

standardrecord.applicability: This Specification was formulated for the purpose of providing a document setting forth engineering and use requirements for optimum use in optical waveguide fibers. Utilization of this document is intended to eliminate misunderstandings or confusion between the supplier and user with respect to product performance requirements and test procedures.

standard.title: Digital Interoperability between UHF satellite communications terminals

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the technical characteristics necessary and sufficient to ensure interoperability of digital voice, data and telegraph between UHF satellite communications (SATCOM) terminals.

standard.title: Digital interoperability between EHF Tactical Satellite Communications Terminals

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the technical characteristics necessary and sufficient to ensure interoperability of digital voice, data and telegraph between EHF satellite communications terminals.

standard.title: ECM-resistant digital traffic exchange between tactical satellite communications terminals(Draft)
Super High Frequency (SHF) Military Satellite (MILSATCOM) jam- resistant modem

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG defines interoperable characteristics of an SHF anti-jam, anti-scitillation, low probability of exploitation satellite communication modem. The purpose is to ensure modem to modem interoperability between NATO forces utilizing SHF transponding satellite systems. It is intended that this STANAG be applicable to all geosynchronous SHF satellite systems.

standard.title: Overall Super High Frequency (SHF) Military Satellite COMmunications (MILSATCOM) interoperability standards, STANAG 4484 ed.2

standardrecord.applicability: The purpose of this standard is to provide a system level definition of SHF Satellite Communications (SATCOM) to achieve interoperability between allied systems. This standard provides the basis to achieve interoperable communications over existing nonprocessing transponders (NATO, DSCS, SKYNET, etc.) and future SHF satellites. This standard provides the pathway to, and applicability of, the necessary information required to provide digital transmission of user supplied information, and to achieve interoperability between ground fixed, ground transportable, ground mobile, airborne, and ship borne SHF satellite terminals.

standard.title: SHF MILSATCOM Non-EPM modem for services conforming to class-A of STANAG 4484, STANAG 4485 ed.1

standardrecord.applicability:
This standard defines interoperable characteristics of an SHF satellite communications modem. A modem compatible with this STANAG will be used to provide communication links through transparent satellite transponders. The purpose of this standard is to ensure modem to modem interoperability between NATO forces utilising SHF transponding satellite systems. It is intended that this standard be applicable to all geosynchronous SHF satellite systems.
This standard defines the interoperable characteristics of an SHF satcom modem for low datarate services defined as Class A in STANAG 4484.

standard.title: Super High Frequency (SHF) Military Satellite COMmunications (MILSATCOM) Frequency Division Multiple Access (FDMA) Non-EPM modem for services conforming to class-B of STANAG 4484 Ed.2

standardrecord.applicability:
This standard defines interoperable characteristics of an SHF satellite communication modem. A modem compatible with this STANAG will be used to provide communication links through transparent satellite transponders. The purpose of this standard is to ensure modem to modem interoperability between NATO forces utilising SHF transponding satellite systems. It is intended that this standard be applicable to all geosynchronous SHF satellite systems.
This standard defines the interoperable characteristics of an SHF satcom non-EPM modem for medium capacity services defined as Class B in STANAG 4484.

standard.title: UHF MILSATCOM interoperability standards for paging receiver STANAG 4492 (Draft)
SHF MILSATCOM network management and control, STANAG 4505 (Draft)

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the technical characteristics (data elements and control message sets) necessary and sufficient for digital interoperability of control links between military satellite communications terminals for a non-EPM capable SHF SATCOM network.

standard.title: EHF MIL SATCOM interoperability standards for medium data rate services (Draft)

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the minimum interoperability modes for a NATO EHF MDR MILSATCOM system. This STANAG describes the EHF MDR signal, modulation, and data format parameters of the satellite data uplinks and downlinks. These standard data links are transmissions that can be used for tracking, commanding, or communications on the uplink and for telemetry, tracking, mission data, or communications on the downlink. When the requirements of the standard are incorporated in specifications and used to develop satellite data links, a basic commonality for the satellite and ground terminal processing equipment is established, and link interoperability is possible.

standard.title: Link control for Super High Frequency (SHF) Military Satellite COMmunications (MILSATCOM) Frequency Division Multiple Access (FDMA) Non-Electronic Protective Measure (Non-EPM) modem for services confirming to class-B of STANAG 4484 (Draft)

standardrecord.applicability: The purpose of this STANAG is to define the interoperability characteristics and their protocols employed on SHF SATCOM systems providing non-EPM services defined as class B in STANAG 4484. Allied systems include Defense Satellite Communications System III, Gapfiller, Advanced Wideband Satellite, NATO III, NATO IV, NATO SATCOM Post 2000, SICRAL, SKYNET 4, SKYNET 5, SPAINSAT, SYRACUSE II, SYRACUSE III, TURKSAT, and future SHF satellites.

standard.title: Super High Frequency (SHF) Medium Data Rate (MDR) Military Satellite COMmunications (MILSATCOM) jam-resistant modem interoperability standards (Draft)

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG defines interoperable characteristics of an SHF anti-jam, low probability of exploitation, low probability of intercept modem for satelllite communications. The purpose of this STANAG is to ensure modem to modem interoperability between NATO forces utilising X-Band transponding satellite systems. It is intended that this STANAG is applicable to all geosynchronous SHF satellite systems.

standard.title: Interoperability standard for Satellite Broadcast Services (SBS), STANAG 4622 (Draft)

standardrecord.applicability: The Satelllite Broadcast System (SBS) will provide NATO forces with high capacity satellite communications for strategic and tactical units. The aim of this STANAG is to define a baseline set of interfaces and protocols so that system integrators are able to build and commission interoperable SBS transmit and receive platforms using COTS based satellite broadcast technology and NATO approved HAIPIS-compliant Type-1 IP-encryption devices.

standard.title: Technical standards for single channel HF radio equipment

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the technical standards required to ensure interoperability of land, air and maritime COMMON single channel HF radio equipment. For technical standards of SPECIFIC single channel radio equipment reference should be made to the appropriate STANAGs (e.g. STANAGs 4444 and 5511).

standard.title: Technical standards for single channel VHF radio equipment

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the technical standards required to ensure interoperability of land, air and maritime single channel VHF radio equipment.

standard.title: Technical standards for single channel UHF radio equipment

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the technical standards required to ensure interoperability of land, air and maritime single channel UHF radio equipment.

standard.title: Standards to Achieve Communication Between Single Channel Tactical Combat Net Radio Equipment and Frequency Hopping Radios Operating in the same VHF (30-108 MHz) Band
Conditions for interoperability of 2400 BPS / HF

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the coding and modulation characteristics to ensure the compatibility of the analogue signal of modems used over single channel high frequency radio facilities for sky-wave transmission of 2400 bps digital voice produced using Linear Predictive Encoding.

standard.title: Characteristics of 1200/2400/ 3600 bps single tone modulators for HF Radio links

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the technical characteristics for communicating over digital data radio channels, the effective bit rate which can be 1200, 2400 or 3600 bits per second, by means of a single tone modulator/demodulator.

standard.title: Characteristics of a Robust, Non-Hopping Serial Tone Modulator/Demodulator For Severely Degraded HF Radio Links

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG defines the technical interoperability characteristics for a means of digital communications over severely degraded HF radio links at an effective bit rate of 75 bits per second.

standard.title: Technical Standards for Non-Secure Voice Interoperability of Very High Frequency (VHF) Combat Net Radios (CNR) by use of Common Interface Radio Adapter Devices

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG defines the technical characteristics for the Radio Adapters and Common Interface Cable that enable non-secure voice interoperability between national Very High Frequency (VHF) Combat Net Radio (CNR) nets.

standard.title: Voice and Data Interface Between Secure VHF EPM Combat Net Radios

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG defines the technical characteristics for a standard interface between VHF combat net radios (CNR). The interface allows voice and digital data communication between national CNR nets which are not directly interoperable.

standard.title: Technical Standards for an Automatic Radio Control System (ARCS) for HF Communication Links

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAg defines the technical standards required to ensure the interoperability of land, air and maritime HF radio equipment operating in an automated mode by means of an automatic radio control system.

standard.title: Technical Standards for non-hopping HF Communications Waveforms

standardrecord.applicability: Moden standard specifying protocols at the physical layer, it is intended for tri-service usage, it covers data ates from 75 bps to 12800 bps by referring to existing standards (STANAG 4415 and MIL-STD 188-110) and by defining new waveforms for data rates from 3200 to 12800 bps. All of the defined waveforms in STANAG 4539 provide autobaud characteristics which, in conjunction with the ARQ protocol, can give automatic adaption of data rates to the channel conditions.

standard.title: Profile for HF radio data communications (Draft)

standardrecord.applicability:
This STANAG describes a profile for data communication over HF radio, nominally for beyond-line-of-sight circuits. The technical characteristics that are required to ensure interoperability and reliable system operation are described in the main body of and mandatory annexes to this STANAG.
The HF profile provides interoperability at the two major interfaces: first, the "common air interface", describing how information is exchanged between nodes by radio; and second, the non-HF interfaces which allow external users or clients to interact with the subnetwork and with each other over the subnetwork. While physical interfaces are left up to the system implementer (e.g., Ethernet, FDDI, internal bus, or shared memory), the data formats (primitives) and procedures that make up the interface are specified in detail so that client applications can make use of the subnet.

standard.title: UHF Radios

standardrecord.applicability:
The aim of this STANAG is to define the timing characteristics, the radio equipment characteristics and interfaces necessary to ensure interoperability of land, air and maritime single channel UHF radio equipment when HAVE QUICK capability is incorporated.
HAVE QUICK is a frequency hopping, jam-resistant technique for both non-secure and secure voice use with single channel, electronically tunable UHF AM radios as described in STANAG 4205 and as supplemented by the technical characteristics listed in Annexes C and D of this STANAG. There are two versions of this technique: HAVE QUICK I and HAVE QUICK II. The HAVE QUICK I mode is not interoperable with the HAVE QUICK II mode because of the different frequencies and net structures used in each mode. The HAVE QUICK II equipment, however, retains all the frequencies and net structures of HAVE QUICK I, as well as its own, to ensure interoperability.

standard.title: MIDS terminals

standardrecord.applicability:
The principle purpose of this STANAG is to define the technical characteristics required to:
Achieve interoperability among MIDS terminals employed by the military services of the nations belonging to NATO (including CCEB nations AS and NZ
Ensure that the electromagnetic emissions from MIDS will not unduly interfere with other users of the frequncy bands employed by MIDS.
Implement network management procedures of STANAG 5516 required for effective system operation.

standard.title: Conformance Testing Methodology and Framework

applicability.para: The Conformance Testing standards define a framework for specifying conformance test suites, and to define the procedures to be followed during testing. The purpose of conformance testing is to increase the probability that different OSI implementations are able to interwork. However it should be borne in mind that the complexity of most protocols makes exhaustive testing impractical on both technical and economical grounds and that conformance to a test suite alone cannot guarantee interworking. The series of standards consists of standards on:

standard.title: OSI transport svc over TCP/IP

standardrecord.applicability: This document describes the mechanism to allow ISO Transport Services to run over TCP over IPv4 or IPv6. It also defines a number of new features, which are not provided in RFC 1006:1987.

standard.title: API Network Process to Process Communication, (SNI/DNI)

standardrecord.applicability: P1003.12 contains the specification for a Simple Network Interface (SNI) and a Detailed Network Interface (DNI). The SNI provides for an communications interface over a number of different transport services (OSI layer 1-4) or even high level services (OSI layer 1-7). The SNI has a very limited set of services with minimal parameters. The DNI offers services over a wide variety of network protocols. DNI allows applications to access low-level details of each of the different network protocols and to optimise the use of the network (OSI layer 1-3). Programs using DNI may be portable between environments that use the same underlying network protocols (OSI layer 1-3). Applications can be written using a combination of SNI and DNI interfaces.

standard.title: Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol (TCP/IP) (IP Version 4)
Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol (TCP/IP) (IP Version 6)

profilerecord.applicability: TCP/IP provides for a reliable, connection-oriented, end-to-end transport service on top of an unreliable network that can lose, garble, store and duplicate packets (in OSI terms a type 'C' network). In this, TCP resembles the OSI Transport Protocol class 4 (TP4) but major differences exist in features like the handling of collisions, addressing format, quality of service, the use of user data during set-up of a connection, the handling of 'important data', the absence of piggybacking in TP4, kind of message streams, flow control handling, window numbering scheme and connection release. TCP also offers some services that in OSI are positioned as 'session-layer' services. Associated with TCP is a network layer protocol called 'Internet Protocol' or 'IP'. TCP/IP can support OSI upper layer applications by employing RFC 2126:1997.

standard.title: Transport Services
Connection-oriented Transport protocol
Connectionless Transport protocol

profilerecord.applicability:
The Transport Services offer the following features to a Transport Service User:
the means to establish one or more end-to-end transport connections to another transport-user.
request and negotiate and agree a quality of service for the Transport Connection.
transferring (expedited) data over a Transport Connection.

standard.title: User Datagram Protocol (UDP)

standardrecord.applicability: UDP provides for a connection-less, end-to-end transport service. UDP allows users to send data messages without connection establishment and without any guarantee of delivery or sequencing. In effect, UDP is simply a user interface to IP. UDP should only be considered where ISO connection-less transport services are not consistent with the system requirements. UDP/IP can support OSI upper layer applications by employing RFC 1240:1991.

standard.title: Microsoft Windows Sockets (Winsock) Version 2.0

standardrecord.applicability: Winsock is a Session layer standard supported by Microsoft and numerous independent software vendors (ISVs) which enables portability and interoperability between Microsoft Windows PCs over TCP/IP, OSI and other transports.

standard.title: Wireless Transaction Processing Protocol, WAP WTP.

standardrecord.applicability:
The following list summarizes the features of WTP.
Three classes of transaction service:
Class 0: Unreliable invoke message with no result message
Class 1: Reliable invoke message with no result message
Class 2: Reliable invoke message with exactly one reliable result message
Reliability is achieved through the use of unique transaction identifiers, acknowledgements, duplicate removal and re-transmissions.
No explicit connection set up or tear down phases. Explicit connection open and/or close imposes excessive overhead on the communication link.
Optionally user-to-user reliability: the WTP user confirms every received message.
Optionally, the last acknowledgement of the transaction MAY contain out of band information related to the transaction. For example, performance measurements.
Concatenation MAY be used, where applicable, to convey multiple Protocol Data Units in one Service Data Unit of the datagram transport.
Message orientation. The basic unit of interchange is an entire message and not a stream of bytes.
The protocol provides mechanisms to minimize the number of transactions being replayed as the result of duplicate packets.
Abort of outstanding transaction, including flushing of unsent data both in client and server. The abort can be triggered by the user canceling a requested service.
For reliable invoke messages, both success and failure is reported. If an invoke can not be handled by the Responder, an abort message will be returned to the Initiator instead of the result.
The protocol allows for asynchronous transactions. The Responder sends back the result as the data becomes available.

standard.title: Federated Naming: The Open Group XFN Specification - CAE Specification

standardrecord.applicability: This Federated Naming (XFN) specification defines the model of a federated naming service together with an associated programmatic interface, and specifies the naming policies to be used in conjunction with this service. Collectively, these definitions are called the XFN specification.

standard.title: SIP URI Service Discovery using DNS-SD:2010

standardrecord.applicability: This document describes how to use the DNS-based Service Discovery (DNS-SD), better known as Apple Bonjour, for advertising Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) URIs in local area networks. Using this mechanism, a SIP user agent (UA) can communicate with another UA even when no SIP registrar is available, as in a wireless ad-hoc network for example.

standard.title: Advanced Encryption Standard 128:2002

standardrecord.applicability: AES 128 specifies an approved cryptographic algorithm that can be used to protect electronic data. AES is a symmetric block cipher that can encrypt (cipher) and decrypt (decipher) information. The AES algorithm is capable of using cryptographic keys of 128, 192 and 256 bits to encrypt and decrypt data in blocks of 128 bits. PKI components and applications should utilize AES for key wrap functions. It may also be applied to locally stored keys generated by the Root Certification Authority.

standard.title: Identification cards - Contactless integrated circuit(s) cards - Proximity cards
Contactless Smartcards Part 1: Physical Characteristics
Contactless Smartcards Part 2: Radio frequency power and signal interface
Contactless Smartcards Part 3: Initialization and anticollision

standardrecord.applicability: Remote-coupling communication cards.

standard.title: Cryptoki, PKCS#11, Vers. 2.10

standardrecord.applicability: Cryptoki ("crypto-key") is part of the RSA's Public Key Cryptography Standards (PKCS) family distributed by RSA. Cryptoki provides a standard low-level CAPI, primarily for access to personal cryptographic tokens.

standard.title: Content Vectoring Protocol v1.01

standardrecord.applicability: CVP was first developed for integration with anti-virus servers. In the second generation, the CVP protocol was developed into an API specification and was enhanced to meet the broader requirements of downloadable executable and mail content security, including the transmission of HTTP headers and SMTP headers which allow for the development of anti-spamming filters.

standard.title: The Directory: Public-key and attribute certificate frameworks

standardrecord.applicability: This document provides a framework for the provision of authentication capabilities to users of the X.500 Directory (defined in ISO/IEC 9594:1995), using credentials stored therein. The framework will also be used by the Directory to authenticate its proper users. This recommendation describes two levels of authentication: simple authentication using a password as a verification of claimed identity, and strong authentication involving credentials formed using cryptographic techniques (public-key crypto system).

standard.title: Digital Signature Standard

standardrecord.applicability: This Standard specifies a suite of algorithms appropriate for applications which can be used to generate a digital signature. As a specific algorithm, it references the Digital Signature Algorithm (DSA). The DSA authenticates the integrity of the signed data and the identity of the signatory. It is used by the PCT within STANAG 4406 Ed.2.

standard.title: Digital Signature Algorithm 1024

standardrecord.applicability: Authentication and integrity algorithm for ?End Entities? a mandated by the interoperability protocol PCT for implementing digital signatures for a NATO Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) in the NATO messaging system. PKI Implementation Guidance is provided in AC/322-D(2004)0035. FIPS 186-2 specifies the DSA that may be used in the generation and verification of digital signatures for sensitive unclassified applications.

standard.title: Generic Cryptographic Service Application Program Interface (GCS-API)

standardrecord.applicability: The Security Working Group (SWG) of the Open group (ex X/Open) consortium is creating a set of APIs and cryptographic mechanisms to provide security services to applications. This API permits to integrate cryptographic functionality into cryptographic-aware applications i.e. applications understanding the basic operation of cryptographic algorithms and key management.

standard.title: Generic Security Service Application Program Interface (GSS-API)

standardrecord.applicability: The Common Authentication Technology (CAT) working group of the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) is creating a set of APIs and cryptographic mechanisms to provide security services to application programmers. This API permits to integrate cryptographic functionality into application software without tightly coupling the application to the cryptographic module. GSS-API is a high level CAPI (Cryptographic API), independent of cryptographic algorithms and applicable to applications unaware of cryptographic techniques.

standard.title: Identification Cards -- Physical Characteristics

standardrecord.applicability: Describes requirements for the physical characteristics of identification cards, specifies card materials, construction, characteristics and dimensions for three sizes of card. Takes into consideration both human and machine aspects.

standard.title: Identification Cards - Integrated Circuit(s) with contacts
Identification Cards with Contacts Part 1: Physical characteristics
Identification Cards with Contacts Part 2: Dimension and location of the contacts
Identification Cards with Contacts Part 3: Electronic interface and transmission protocols
Identification Cards with Contacts Part 4: Organization, security and commands for interchange
Identification Cards with Contacts Part 5: Registration of application providers

standardrecord.applicability: Describes requirements for the physical characteristics of identification cards, specifies card materials, construction, characteristics and dimensions for three sizes of card. Takes into consideration both human and machine aspects.

standard.title: Identification Cards - Identification of Issuers
Identification of Issuers Part 1: Numbering System
Identification of Issuers Part 2: Application and Registration Procedures

standardrecord.applicability: Lays down a numbering system for identifying issuers of identification cards. Specifies the procedures to be used for the registration and publication of issuer identification numbers.

profilerecord.profilenote: Internet Protocol (IP) Security

standard.title: Security Architecture for the Internet Protocol
IP Authentication Header (AH)
The Use of HMAC-MD5_96 within ESP and AH
The Use of HMAC-SHA-1-96 within ESP and AH
The ESP DES-CBC Cipher Algorithm with Explicit IV
IP Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP)
The Internet IP Security Domain of Interpretation for ISAKMP
Internet Security Association and Key Management Protocol (ISAKMP)
The Internet Key Exchange (IKE)
The NULL Encryption Algorithm and Ist Use With IPSec
The OAKLEY Key Determination Protocol

profilerecord.applicability:
IPsec is designed to provide interoperable, high quality, cryptographically-based security for IPv4 and IPv6. The set of security services offered includes access control, connectionless integrity, data origin authentication, protection against replays (a form of partial sequence integrity), confidentiality (encryption), and limited traffic flow confidentiality. These services are provided at the IP layer, offering protection for IP and/or upper layer protocols. These objectives are met through the use of two traffic security protocols, the Authentication Header (AH) and the Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP), and through the use of cryptographic key management procedures and protocols. The set of IPsec protocols employed in any context, and the ways in which they are employed, will be determined by the security and system requirements of users, applications, and/or sites/organizations.
IPsec provides security services at the IP layer by enabling a system to select required security protocols, determine the algorithm(s) to use for the service(s), and put in place any cryptographic keys required to provide the requested services. IPsec can be used to protect one or more "paths" between a pair of hosts, between a pair of security gateways, or between a security gateway and a host.
A basic and mandatory element of IPSec is the usage of Security Associations. A Security Association (SA) is a simplex "connection" that affords security services to the traffic carried by it. Security services are afforded to an SA by the use of AH, or ESP, but not both. If both AH and ESP protection is applied to a traffic stream, then two (or more) SAs are created to afford protection to the traffic stream. To secure typical, bi-directional communication between two hosts, or between two security gateways, two Security Associations (one in each direction) are required.
The key management protocol must be robust in order to handle public key generation for the Internet community at large and private key requirements for those private networks with that requirement. The Internet Security Association and Key Management Protocol (ISAKMP) defines the procedures for authenticating a communicating peer, creation and management of Security Associations, key generation techniques, and threat mitigation (e.g. denial of service and replay attacks). All of these are necessary to establish and maintain secure communications (via IP Security Service or any other security protocol) in an Internet environment.

standard.title: Common ISIS-Mailtrust Specifications for Interoperable PKI Applications

standardrecord.applicability: The ISIS-MTT Specification describes data formats and communication protocols to be employed in interoperable PKI-based applications. The specification focuses on security services for authentication (including user identification and data integrity), confidentiality and non-repudiation. The specification concentrates on interoperability aspects, embracing different on-line services of certification service providers (CSPs), such as certification service, directory service and time-stamp service, as well as client applications accessing and relying on those services. As most important target application area, data formats for the secure interchange of emails and files via Internet are defined.

standard.title: JAVACard 2.2.1 Platform Specification v.2.2.2:2006

standardrecord.applicability: The JAVA Card specifications enable JAVA technology to run on smart cards and other devices with limited memory.

profilerecord.profilenote: Web Services Security 1.0

standard.title: Web Services Security: SOAP Message Security V1.0
Web Services Security: Username Token Profile V1.0
Web Services Security: X.509 Token Profile V1.0

profilerecord.applicability:
WS-Security describes enhancements to SOAP messaging to provide quality of protection through message integrity, message confidentiality, and single message authentication. These mechanisms can be used to accommodate a wide variety of security models and encryption technologies.
WS-Security also provides a general-purpose mechanism for associating security tokens with messages. No specific type of security token is required by WS-Security. It is designed to be extensible (e.g. support multiple security token formats). For example, a client might provide proof of identity and proof that they have a particular business certification.
Additionally, WS-Security describes how to encode binary security tokens. Specifically, the specification describes how to encode X.509 certificates and Kerberos tickets as well as how to include opaque encrypted keys. It also includes extensibility mechanisms that can be used to further describe the characteristics of the credentials that are included with a message.

standard.title: Open Systems Interconnection Security Architecture

standardrecord.applicability: This standard gives a description of security services and associated mechanisms, which may be provided in the OSI reference model, and defines their location in the OSI architecture.

standard.title: PC/SC Workgroup Specifications Overview:v.2.0.1.9:2005
PC/SC Part 1: Introduction and Architecture Overview
PC/SC Part 2: Interface Requirements for Compatible IC Cards and Readers
PC/SC Part 3: Requirements for PC-Connected Interface Devices
PC/SC Part 4: IFD Design Considerations and Reference Design Information
PC/SC Part 5: ICC Resource Manager Definition
PC/SC Part 6: ICC Service Provider Interface Specification
PC/SC Part 7: Application Domain and Developer Design Consideration
PC/SC Part 8: Recommendations for ICC Security and Privacy Devices

standardrecord.applicability: PC/SC work builds upon existing industry smart card standards - ISO/IEC 7816 and EMV - and complements them by defining low-level device interfaces and device-independent application APIs as well as resource management, to allow multiple applications to share smart card devices attached to a system.

standard.title: Remote Authentication Dial In User Service (RADIUS):2006

standardrecord.applicability: TThis document describes a protocol for carrying authentication, authorization, and configuration information between a Network Access Server which desires to authenticate its links and a shared Authentication Server.

standard.title: RADIUS and IPv6

standardrecord.applicability: This document specifies the operation of RADIUS (Remote Authentication Dial In User Service) when run over IPv6 as well as the RADIUS attributes used to support IPv6 network access.

standard.title: Digital Signature Algorithm RSA 2048

standardrecord.applicability:
Authentication and integrity algorithm for ?Sub Certification Authority and other PKI components (such as Key Recovery Agents)? as mandated by the interoperability protocol PCT for implementing digital signatures for a NATO Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) in the NATO messaging system. PKCS#1 v2.1 provides recommendations for the implementation of public-key cryptography based on the RSA algorithm, covering
Cryptographic primitives
Encryption schemes
Signature schemes with appendix
ASN.1 syntax for representing keys and for identifying the schemes
The recommendations are intended for general application within computer and communications systems, and as such include a fair amount of flexibility. It is expected that application standards based on these specifications may include additional constraints. The recommendations are intended to be compatible with the standard IEEE-1363-2000 and draft standards currently being developed by the ANSI X9F1 and IEEE P1363 working groups.

standard.title: S/MIME Version 3 Certificate Handling
S/MIME Version 3 Message Specification

profilerecord.applicability: S/MIME (Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions), provides a method to send and receive secure MIME messages. Before using a public key to provide security services, the S/MIME agent must certify that the public key is valid. S/MIME agentsmust use PKIX certificates to validate public keys as described in the Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure (PKIX) Certificate and CRL Profile. S/MIME agents must meet the certificate processing requirements documented in this document in addition to those stated in X.509.

standard.title: Secure Hash Standard

standardrecord.applicability: This Standard specifies a Secure Hash Algorithm, SHA-1, for computing a condensed representation of a message or a data file. When a message of any length < 2**64 bits is input, the SHA-1 produces a 160-bit output called a message digest. The message digest can then be input to the Digital Signature Algorithm (DSA) which generates or verifies the signature for the message. Signing the message digest rather than the message often improves the efficiency of the process because the message digest is usually much smaller in size than the message. The same hash algorithm must be used by the verifier of a digital signature as was used by the creator of the digital signature.

standard.title: Secure Hash Algorithm 256, SHA-256:2002

standardrecord.applicability: Hash algorithm to accompany the DSA and RSA for use in NMS. FIPS 180-2 specifies four secure hash algorithms SHA-1, SHA-256, SHA-384 and SHA-512 for computing a condensed representation of electronic data (message). When a message of any length smaller than 2**64 bits (for SHA-1 and SHA-256) and smaller than 2**128 bits (for SHA-384 and SHA-512) as input top the algorithm, the result is an output called a message digest which can range in length from 160 to 512 bits, depending on the algorithm. Secure hash algorithms in NATO are typically used with digital signature algorithms.

standard.title: Standard for Interoperable LAN Security (SILS)
Security Architecture Framework
Secure Data Exchange
Key Management
Security Management

standardrecord.applicability:
The standard provides different service interfaces for key management, secure data exchange, and security management.
Security management may be expanded to include fault, performance and configuration management as well. In addition, IEEE P802.2 is considering an optional security sub-layer for logical link control.

standard.title: A One-Time Password System

standardrecord.applicability: This document describes a one-time password authentication system (OTP). The system provides authentication for system access (login) and other applications requiring authentication that is secure against passive attacks based on replaying captured reusable passwords. OTP evolved from the S/KEY. One-Time Password System was originally released by Bellcore.

standard.title: Single Sign On

standardrecord.applicability: High value business information is increasingly being maintained within multiple data processing systems in distributed system architectures. Security for each system demands effective access controls whilst administrators are faced with significant overheads for handling multiple accounts for each user.
