XXSO-PAM provides a standard interface between applications and sign-on systems so that whatever the underlying technology of the application's authentication technology, they will plug-and-play with a "coordinating "primary" single sign-on system. This enables applications and their host systems to continue to maintain their own account databases, but it also enables those applications to move towards use of the more strategic distributed security services, enabling migration from multiple uncoordinated security systems to a coherent security architecture for all applications. PAM also simplifies some aspects of security management. The XSSO-PAM Specification therefore supports a practical approach which enables sign-on (SSO) for applications in a distributed environment.

standard.title: Integrated Circuit Card Specifications for Payment Systems
Smartcard Specifications - Book 1: Application Independent ICC to Terminal Interface Requirements
Smartcard Specifications - Book 2: Security and Key Management
Smartcard Specifications - Book 3: Application Specification
Smartcard Specifications - Book 4: Cardholder, Attendant, and Acquirer Interface Requirements

standardrecord.applicability: Europay, MasterCard and Visa have created their "integrated Circuit Card Specifications for Payment systems". The specification is intended to create common technical basis for card and system implementation of a stored value system.

standard.title: Secure Socket Layer, vers. 3.0

standardrecord.applicability: This standard specifies Version 3.0 of the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL V3.0) protocol, a security protocol that provides communications privacy over the Internet. The protocol allows client/server applications to communicate in a way that is designed to prevent eavesdropping, tampering, or message forgery.

history.event: Originally placed as a datainterchange standard

standard.title: Transport Layer Security (TLS)

standardrecord.applicability: This document specifies Version 1.2 of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. The TLS protocol provides communications security over the Internet. The protocol allows client/server applications to communicate in a way that is designed to prevent eavesdropping, tampering, or message forgery. .

standard.title: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol

standardrecord.applicability: This memo defines the Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP). VRRP specifies an election protocol that dynamically assigns responsibility for a virtual router to one of the VRRP routers on a LAN. The VRRP router controlling the IP address(es) associated with a virtual router is called the Master, and forwards packets sent to these IP addresses. The election process´ provides dynamic fail over in the forwarding responsibility should the Master become unavailable. This allows any of the virtual router IP addresses on the LAN to be used as the default first hop router by end-hosts. The advantage gained from using VRRP is a higher availability default path without requiring configuration of dynamic routing or router discovery protocols on every end-host.

standard.title: Message transfer system: Abstract service definition and procedures

standardrecord.applicability: This security service augments the Message Security Labeling service by allowing the originator to convey to all recipients of an interpersonal message an indication of the sensitivity of the IPM content, or optionally, of the component heading and body parts ofan IPM. This service enables the implementation of security policies in which the securitylabels associated with local objects (e.g., files) derived from component parts of the IPM may be assigned values provided by the originating IPMS-user. The integrity and confidentiality of the IPM Security Information Label are provided by the Content Integrity and the Content Confidentiality security services. Authentication of the originator of the IPM Security Information Label is provided by the Message Origin Authentication service

standard.title: SCIP Signalling Plan rev.3

standardrecord.applicability:
This document specifies the signaling requirements for the Secure Communication Interoperability Protocol (SCIP) operational modes. The requirements represent the efforts of a working group established for the development, analysis, selection, definition and refinement of signaling for the operational modes of a new class of secure voice and data terminals intended for use on the emerging digital narrowband channels. These channels include digital cellular systems such as GSM and CDMA, digital mobile satellite systems, and a variety of other narrowband digital systems that are also within the scope of interest for the working group. The SCIP signaling is designed to be sufficiently flexible so that subsequent updates and revisions may include various future networks of interest.
For details, contact AC/322 (SC/4).

standard.title: Network-Specific Minimum Essential Requirements (MERs) for SCIP Devices, rev.1.1

standardrecord.applicability:
This document provides an index to the specifications of the network-specific interface Minimum Essential Requirements (MERs) for Secure Communication Interoperability Protocol (SCIP) devices. The MERs for each network-specific interface are defined in separate SCIP-214 modules that are independently under configuration control. This document also provides a SCIP network architecture diagram and the SCIP Document Family Tree of Interface Requirements.
For details, contact AC/322 (SC/4).

standard.title: Secure Communications Interoperability Protocol ECMQV/AES Cryptography Specification, rev.1.1

standardrecord.applicability:
This document specifies the cryptography requirements and associated Interoperable Non-Type 1 Operational Modes for the Secure Communications Interoperability Protocol (SCIP) family of equipment. The key negotiation primitive is Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) MQV using the Full MQV scheme. AES-256 is the traffic encryption algorithm. The Certification Authority (CA) will generate X.509 Certificates to be delivered with the ECC static private component in key material loads that will be incorporated into a software download via PC compatible means. Counter mode cryptography will be used in conjunction with the AES algorithm. Encrypted Packet methodology for Traffic key validation is used. All standard SCIP voice and data applications are supported.
For details, contact AC/322 (SC/4).

standard.title: XMPP core
XMPP Instant Messaging and Presence
Mapping XMPP to CPIM
End-to-End Signing and Encryption

profilerecord.applicability: This standard defines the features of the Extensible Messaging and Presence Protocol (XMPP), a protocol for streaming Extensible Markup Language (XML) elements in order to exchange structured information in close to real time between any two network endpoints. While XMPP provides a generalized, extensible framework for exchanging XML data, it is used mainly for the purpose of building instant messaging and presence applications that meet the requirements of RFC 2779.

standard.title: Draft Security Interface Standards for POSIX

standardrecord.applicability: The P1003.1e document defines security extensions to the basic POSIX 1003.1 standard, and provides protection, audit and control interfaces (in C language). It includes the following mechanisms: access control lists, audit, privilege, mandatory access control and information labelling. The P1003.2e document defines security extensions to the POSIX 1003.2 standard, and provides protection and control utilities associated to the security mechanisms defined in P1003.1e.

standard.title: Security in Open Systems - Data Elements and Service Definitions

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines services and protocols for security in open systems and provide a public key-based specification for distributed authentication.

standard.title: Security Techniques - Evaluation criteria for IT security:2009
ITSEC/CC Part 1: Introduction and general model
ITSEC/CC Part 2: Security functional requirements
ITSEC/CC Part 3: Security assurance requirements
NATO Trusted Computer System Evaluation Criteria (NTCSEC)

standardrecord.applicability: The NTCSEC document is modelled after the TCSEC document. It is applicable to address NATO information systems.

standard.title: NATO OSI Security Architecture, NOSA

standardrecord.applicability: NOSA was developed by the TSGCE SG9 Ad Hoc Working Group (AHWG) on Security to give guidance to contractors and procurement managers on the preferred placement of security services within OSI-conferment systems. The emphasis has been to derive appropriate refinements and augmentations to ISO/IEC 7498-2 so that a comprehensive set of security facilities can be defined to satisfy the NATO secure interoperability requirements. The AHWG has also developed a document called SANISI (Security Architecture for NATO Information System Interconnection) which provides more detailed rationale on the placement of security services and mechanisms within the NATO OSI Reference Model.

standard.title: Security Framework in Open Systems
Security Framework in Open Systems Part 1: Overview
Security Framework in Open Systems Part 2: Authentication framework
Security Framework in Open Systems Part 3: Access control framework
Security Framework in Open Systems Part 4: Non-repudiation framework
Security Framework in Open Systems Part 5: Confidentiality framework
Security Framework in Open Systems Part 6: Integrity framework
Security Framework in Open Systems Part 7: Security audit and alarms framework

standardrecord.applicability: This document defines the framework within which security services for open systems (i.e. database, distributed applications, ODP and OSI) are specified, and addresses data elements and sequences of operations (but not protocol elements) that are used to obtain security services. These security services may apply to the communicating entities of systems as well as to data exchanged between systems and to data managed by systems.

standard.title: US DoD Trusted Computer System Evaluation Criteria (TCSEC), (the Orange Book)

standardrecord.applicability:
The TCSEC document defines the criteria against which a multi-user operating system will be evaluated. These criteria are organised into classes rated from D to A1 and permit to evaluate the degree of trust that can be placed in a computer system for the secure processing of classified and other sensitive information.
TCSEC provides 7 classes (profiles) :
D : no security
C1 (discretionary security protection): this class satisfies the discretionary security requirement by providing separation of users and data. It incorporates some form of credible controls capable of enforcing access limitations on an individual basis
C2 (controlled access protection): this class enforces a more finely grained discretionary access control than C1, making users individually accountable for their actions through login procedures, auditing of security-relevant events and resource isolation.
B1 (labelled security protection): this class requires all the features required for C2 with, in addition, an informal statement of the security policy model, data labelling and mandatory access control over names subjects and objects.
B2 (structured protection): this requires the discretionary and mandatory access control enforcement found in B1 to be extended to all subjects and objects in the ADP system. In addition, covert channels are addressed. Authentication mechanisms are strengthened, trusted facility management is provided in the form of support for system administrator and operator functions, and stringent configuration management controls are imposed.
B3 (security domains): this class requires a reference monotor that mediates all accesses of subjects to objects, is tamperproof and small enough to be subjected to analysis and tests. A security administrator is supported, audit mechanisms are expanded to signal security-relevant events and system recovery procedures are required.
A1 (verified design): this class is functionally equivalent to B3 but the distinguishing feature of systems in this class is the analysis derived from formal design specification and verification techniques and the resulting high degree of assurance that the system is correctly implemented.

standard.title: Trusted Database Management System Interpretation of the TCSEC (TDI)

standardrecord.applicability: This document extends the Orange Book (TCSEC) to include criteria in the database areas.

standard.title: Trusted Network Interpretation of the TCSEC, (TNI), Version 1

standardrecord.applicability: This document extends the Orange Book (TCSEC) to include criteria in the network areas.

standard.title: Management Information Services - Structure of Management information
SMI Part 1: Management information model
SMI Part 2: Definition of management information
SMI Part 4: Guidelines for definition of managed objects
SMI Part 5: Generic management information
SMI Part 6: Requirements and guidelines for implementation conformance statement proformas associated with OSI management
SMI Part 7: General relationship model
SMI Part 8: Managed objects for supporting upper layer
SMI Part 9: Systems management application layer managed objects

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines the structure of OSI systems management standards. Part 2 defines the managed objects, attributes, bindings, notifications, and action types required by system management. Part 4 specifies the notation tools and templates for defining management information. Part 5 defines the support-managed objects and the services required to control the event reports exchanged among management systems. Part 6 provides the requirements and guidelines for the specification of conformance statement proformas for implementation, managed objects, and management information.

standard.title: Structure of Management Information

standardrecord.applicability: This memo describes a straight-forward approach toward producing concise, yet descriptive, MIB modules. It is intended that all future MIB modules be written in this format.

standard.title: System Management Part 1: Object Management Function
System Management Part 2: State Management Function
System Management Part 3: Attributes for representing relationships
System Management Part 10: Usage metering function for accounting purposes
System Management Part 16: Management knowledge management function
System Management Part 17: Change over function
System Management Part 18: Software Management Function
System Management Part 19: Management Domain and Management Policy Management Functions
System Management Part 20: Time management function (ITU-T Rec. X743)
System Management Part 21: Command Sequencer
System Management Part 22: Response time monitoring function

profilerecord.applicability: Part 1 applies to an environment where two end-systems act in complementary roles, one end-system acting in the manager role while another end-system acts in the agent role. It establishes the requirements for the support of notification services for reporting the managed object creation, managed object deletion and changes in the values of attributes of managed objects. Part 2 establishes the models that relate the service and generic definitions required by the systems management and notification functions. Part 3 defines a set of generic relationships that may exist between managed objects and the services required for reading or modifying them or to notify the changes in a managed object's relationship. Part 16 identifies the set of requirements satisfied by the function, and provides a model for the behaviour of the management knowledge objects. Part 17 establishes user requirements for the service definition needed to support the change over function, and defines the services provided by the function. Part 18 includes software transfer, activation, de-activation, reversion, validation, and enquiry. Part 19 specifies management domain and policy functions. Part 20 specifies requirements for the time management function. Part 21 defines the Command Sequencer, which consists of generic definitions, services and functional units. Part 22 addresses response time monitoring.

standard.title: Common Information Model (CIM) v2.2

standardrecord.applicability: The DMTF Common Information Model (CIM) is an approach to the management of systems and networks that applies the basic structuring and conceptualization techniques of the object-oriented paradigm. The approach uses a uniform modeling formalism that - together with the basic repertoire of object-oriented constructs - supports the cooperative development of an object-oriented schema across multiple organizations. A management schema is provided to establish a common conceptual framework at the level of a fundamental typology - both with respect to classification and association, and with respect to a basic set of classes intended to establish a common framework for a description of the managed environment.

standard.title: Common Management Information Protocol (CMIP)
CMIP Specification
CMIP Protocol Implementation Conformance Statements (PICS)

standardrecord.applicability: This standard (CMIP) specifies the protocol elements that may be used to provide the operation and notification services described in ISO 9595 which defines CMIS. This standard consists of two parts, Part 1: Specification, and Part 2: Protocol Implementation Conformance Statement (PICS) proforma which presents the selected services and protocol options to be implemented in systems in tabular form.

standard.title: Common Management Information Service (CMIS) Definition

standardrecord.applicability: This standard (CMIS) defines an application service element which may be used by an application process in a centralised or distributed management environment to exchange information and commands for systems management as defined by the OSI management framework in ISO/IEC 7498-4.

standard.title: Definitions of Managed Objects for the Ethernet-like Interface Types

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines a portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in the Internet community. In particular, it defines objects for managing Ethernet-like objects.

standard.title: Guidelines for the Definition of Managed Objects:1996
Host Resources Management Information Base (MIB)

standardrecord.applicability: This RFC specifies an Internet standards track protocol for the Internet community. It defines a MIB for use with managing host systems. The term "host" is construed to mean any computer that communicates with other similar computers attached to the Internet and that is directly used by one or more human beings. Although this MIB does not necessarily apply to devices whose primary function is a communication service (e.g., terminal servers, routers, bridges, monitoring equipment), such relevance is not explicitly precluded. This MIB instruments attributes common to all internet hosts including, for example, both personal computers and systems that run variants of Unix.

standard.title: IPv6 MIB

standardrecord.applicability:
This document is one in the series of documents that provide MIB definitions for for IPv6. Specifically, the IPv6 MIB textual conventions as well as the IPv6 MIB General group is defined in this document.
This memo defines a portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in the IPv6-based internets.
This document specifies a MIB module in a manner that is both compliant to the SNMPv2 SMI, and semantically identical to the peer SNMPv1 definitions.

standard.title: Multicast Group Membership Discovery MIB

standardrecord.applicability: This document defines a portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in Internet Protocol Version 6 internets. In particular, it describes objects used for managing the Internet Group Management Protocol (IGMP) and the Multicast Listener Discovery (MLD) protocol.

standard.title: ICMPv6 MIB

standardrecord.applicability:
This document is one in the series of documents that define various MIB object groups for IPv6. Specifically, the ICMPv6 group is defined in this document.
This memo defines a portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in the IPv6-based internets.
This document specifies a MIB module in a manner that is both compliant to the SNMPv2 SMI, and semantically identical to the peer SNMPv1 definitions.

standard.title: IPv6 MIB for TCP

standardrecord.applicability: This memo defines an experimental portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in IPv6-based internets.

standard.title: IPv6 MIB for UDP

standardrecord.applicability: This memo defines an experimental portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in IPv6-based internets.

standard.title: Management Information Base v2 (MIB II)

standardrecord.applicability: This memo defines the second version of the Management Information Base (MIB-II) for use with network management protocols in TCP/IP-based internets. In particular, together with its companion memos which describe the structure of management information (RFC 1155:1990) along with the network management protocol (RFC 1157:1990) for TCP/IP-based internets, these documents provide a simple, workable architecture and system for managing TCP/IP-based internets and in particular the Internet community.

standard.title: OMNIPoint, Network Management Forum (NMF)

standardrecord.applicability: OMNIPoint stands for Open Management Network Interoperability Point. OMNIPoint defines points along a path leading to a fully integrated and automated management environment for networked information systems. OMNIPoint defines a complete infrastructure that enables management systems to interoperate and exchange information in a common way. Building upon international standards, OMNIPoint includes information at a level of detail that supports implementation using today's technology.

standard.title: OSPF version 2 Management Information Base:2006
Remote Network Monitoring Management Information Base, RMON-MIB version 1

standardrecord.applicability: Use with SNMP to provide managers with the ability to monitor Local Area Networks. May be superseded by RMON2 that provides more features including RMON analysis up to the application layer.

standard.title: Remote Network Monitoring Management Information Base, RMON-MIB version 2 using SMIv2

standardrecord.applicability: Emerging standard that may be used on SNMP networks to provide managers with the facilities of RMON MIB V1 plus the ability to monitor end-to-end communications paths.

standard.title: Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP)
SNMP Structure of Management Information (SMI)
standard.comment: specifies how SNMP objects are defined

profilerecord.applicability: SNMP is a protocol used to exchange management information between a Management-manager and Management-agents. An agent manages an object (system, device, etc.) on behalf of the Manager. The basic responsibility of an agent is to keep information about the objects. The agent stores the information and then responds to a manager request or can generate unsolicited responses. By placing the brunt of the processing on the Manager side, able to limit the agent to a few easily deployed functions. As with CMIP, ASN.1 is used to define object classes, which are documented in the appropriate TCP/IP MIB (RFC 1213:1991), and in other more specialised MIBs that address such network components as Token Ring, FDDI and particular routers.

standard.title: Protocol Operations for Version 2 of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMPv2)
Structure of Management Information for Version 2 of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMPv2)
standard.comment: specifies how SNMPv2 objects are defined

standard.title: Management Information Base for Version 2 of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMPv2)
Transport Mappings for Version 2 of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMPv2)
standard.comment: which describes that SNMPv2 can be used on a variety of protocol profiles

standard.title: Coexistence between Version 1 and Version 2 of the Internet-standard Network Management Framework

profilerecord.applicability: SNMPv2 is a protocol used to exchange management information between a Management-manager and Management-agents or another Management-manager. An agent manages an object (system, device, etc.) on behalf of the Manager. The basic responsibility of an agent is to keep information about the objects. The agent stores the information and then responds to a manager request or can generate unsolicited responses. By placing the brunt of the processing on the Manager side, able to limit the agent to a few easily deployed functions. As with CMIP, ASN.1 is used to define object classes, which are documented in the appropriate TCP/IP MIB (RFC 2011:1996 - 2013:1996), and in other more specialised MIBs that address such network components as Token Ring, FDDI and particular routers.

standard.title: Architecture for Describing SNMP Management Frameworks (SNMPv3 Architecture)
Message Processing and Dispatching for the Simple Nemwork Management Protocol (SNMPv3 Management Protocol)
SNMPv3 Applications
User-based Security Model (USM) for version 3 of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMPv3)
View-based Access Control Model (VACM) for version 3 of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMPv3)

profilerecord.applicability:
SNMPv3 is an extensible SNMP Framework which supplements the SNMPv2 Framework, by supporting the following:
A new SNMP message format,
Security for Messages, and
Access Control.
It contains a message-processing model, which is responsible for processing a SNMP version-specific message and for coordinating the interaction with the Security Subsystem to ensure proper security is applied to the SNMP message being handled. The Access Control Subsystem is responsible for checking whether a specific type of access to a particular managed object is allowed,

standard.title: OSI Performance Management Part 11: Metric Objects and Attributes
OSI Performance Management Part 12: Test Management Function
OSI Performance Management Part 13: Summarisation Function
OSI Performance Management Part 14: Confidence and Diagnostic Test Categories
OSI Performance Management Part 15: Scheduling Function

profilerecord.applicability: Part 11 specifies the model objects and algorithms required to monitor and control the workload of the management system. Part 12 specifies the model for establishing compliance requirements for testing the systems management function. Part 13 provides the ability to aggregate observed attribute values and provides statistical information about those values. Part 14 provides the ability to proactively test the health and operation of the management system. Part 15 provides for the scheduling of managed objects.

standard.title: Data Communications Systems and Services - User Oriented Performance Parameters

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines parameters that can be used to describe the performance of data communications services. Parameters describe performance between pairs of users and apply to all classes of data communication systems and services.

standard.title: Data Communications Systems and Services - Measurement Methods for User-Oriented Performance Evaluation

standardrecord.applicability: This standard provides uniform methods of measuring values for the parameters described in ANSI X3.102. The may be used in measuring performance values at any pair of digital interfaces connecting a data communication system to its users.

standard.title: OSI Fault Management Part 4: Alarm reporting function
OSI Fault Management Part 5: Event report management function
OSI Fault Management Part 6: Log control function

profilerecord.applicability: Part 4 defines a set of generic alarms that managed objects may send to a managing system. The alarms are used to notify of failures or abnormal situations. Part 5 defines the support managed objects and the services required to control the event reports exchanged among management systems. Part 6 defines a model for maintaining an ongoing record of activity of the operational and administrative state of the system.

standard.title: OSI Security Management Part 7: Security alarm reporting function
OSI Security Management Part 8: Security audit trail function
OSI Security Management Part 9: Objects and attributes for access control

profilerecord.applicability: Part 7 defines a set of generic security alarms that managed objects may send to a managing system. The alarms are used to notify of breaches in security. Part 8 defines the systems management functions of tracking and logging security events that occur in the management domain. Part 9 specifies the requirements for protecting management information from unauthorised creation, deletion, modification, or disclosure by means of OSI management operations.

standard.title: X/Open Systems Management: Distributed Software Administration

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines a mechanism for addressing the interoperability needs of the IEEE POSIX 1387.2 standard for Software Administration. The POSIX standard does not address interoperability, so this specification defines the necessary additions for operation in a distributed environment. It makes use of the DCE RPC technology to provide interoperability between implementations.

standard.title: OSI Basic Reference Model, Management Framework Part 4: Management Framework

standardrecord.applicability: This reference model provides a management framework describing the activities necessary for systems to interwork using communications media. It provides for a common basis for the co-ordinated development of management standards. It outlines the OSI management functional areas of fault management, accounting management, configuration management, performance management, and security management.

standard.title: Systems Management Overview

standardrecord.applicability: This document provides the system management overview for monitoring, controlling, and co-ordinating the resources of the OSI environment and protocol standards for communicating information pertinent to those resources.

standard.title: 40, 32, 24, 16 kbit/s adaptive differential pulse code modulation (ADPCM)

standardrecord.applicability: Specifies an alternative voice coding e.g. for standard narrowband ISDN telephone systems with 16, 24, 32, 40 kb/s bandwidth requirements.

standard.title: Volume and file structure of CD-ROM for information interchange

standardrecord.applicability: An ISO 9660 file system is a standard CD-ROM file system that allows you to read the same CD-ROM whether you're on a PC, Mac, or other major computer platform. The standard, issued in 1988, was written by an industry group named High Sierra. Almost all computers with CD-ROM drives can read files from an ISO 9660 file system.

standard.title: Code Extended Linear Predictive Coding

standardrecord.applicability: Various attempts have been made to encode the residue signal in an efficient way, providing better quality speech than LPC-10e without increasing the bit rate too much. The most successful methods use a codebook, a table of typical residue signals, which is set up by the system designers. In operation, the analyzer compares the residue to all the entries in the codebook, chooses the entry which is the closest match, and just sends the code for that entry. The synthesizer receives this code, retrieves the corresponding residue from the codebook, and uses that to excite the formant filter. Schemes of this kind are called Code Excited Linear Prediction (CELP). For CELP to work well, the codebook must be big enough to include all the various kinds of residues. But if the codebook is too big, it will be time consuming to search through, and it will require large codes to specify the desired residue. The biggest problem is that such a system would require a different code for every frequency of the source (pitch of the voice), which would make the codebook extremely large.

standard.title: Delta Modulation (DM), EUROCOM D/0

standardrecord.applicability: Delta modulation (DM) is a 1-bit DPCM, namely a DPCM that uses only two levels (or 1 bit) to quantize the prediction error. This leads to very simple transmitter/receiver circuits, which is the primary attraction of DM. Clearly, neighboring signal samples must be highly correlated for DM to give an accurate approximation of the original. This means that signals must be sampled at rates much higher (typically 4-6) than needed for standard 8-bit DPCM.

standard.title: Digital cellular telecommunications system (Phase 2+) (GSM); Full rate speech, Transcoding, version 8.1.1:1999
Digital cellular telecommunications system (Phase 2+), Half rate speech, Half rate speech transcoding, version 8.0.1:2000

profilerecord.applicability: GSM 06.10 specifies the detailed mapping between input blocks of 160 speech samples in 13 bit uniform PCM format to encoded blocks of 260 bits and from encoded blocks of 260 bits to output blocks of 160 reconstructed speech samples. The sampling rate is 8000 samples/s leading to an average bit rate for the encoded bit stream of 13 kbit/s. The encoding scheme is the so-called Regular Pulse Excitation Long Term prediction Linear Predictive Coder, here-after referred as RPE-LTP. The document also specifies the conversion between A- and u-law (PCS 1900) PCM and 13 bit uniform PCM. The second document specifies the speech codec to be used for the GSM half rate channel.

standard.title: Linear Predictive Coding at 2400 b/s, ed.1

standardrecord.applicability: Linear Predictive Coding (LPC) is one of the most powerful speech analysis techniques, and one of the most useful methods for encoding good quality speech at a low bit rate. It provides extremely accurate estimates of speech parameters, and is relatively efficient for computation. LPC-10e provides intelligible speech transmission at 2400 bits per second.

standard.title: Mixed-Excitation Linear Predictive Coding

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG contains design requirements for analog-to-digital conversion of voice by 2,400 bit/s Enhanced Mixed Excitation Linear Prediction (MELPe). The design requirements are also included for an adaptation of MELPe for use at 1,200 bit/s. In addition, the STANAG contains the design requirements for a noise preprocessor that, used in conjunction with the MELPe coder will result in improved voice quality. MELPe is designed as an alternative for CELP. MELPe is robust in difficult background noise environments such as frequently encountered in commercial and military communication systems.

standard.title: Coding of Moving Pictures and Associated Audio for Digital Storage Media at up to about 1.5 Mbit/s:
MPEG-1 Part 1: Systems
MPEG-1 Part 2: Video
MPEG-1 Part 3: Audio
MPEG-1 Part 4: Compliance testing
MPEG-1 Part 5: Software simulation

standardrecord.applicability:
Substantial computing power is required to encode MPEG data in real time. MPEG-1 is optimal for a variety of data rates up to 1.5 megabits per second.
MPEG-1 compression techniques are geared to asymmetric applications where the decompression process is extremely faster than the compression process. Applications making heavy use of this technology include electronic publishing, video games, and delivery of movies. It is also used extensively for downloading and uploading video on the World Wide Web. The shell format is interoperable across platforms and considered to be platform independent.

standard.title: Generic Coding of Moving Pictures and Associated Audio (MPEG-2)
MPEG-2 Part 1: Systems
MPEG-2 Part 2: Video
MPEG-2 Part 3: Audio
MPEG-2 Part 4: Conformance Testing
MPEG-2 Part 5: Software simulation
MPEG-2 Part 6: Extension for Digital Storage Media Command and Control (DSM-CC)
MPEG-2 Part 7: Advanced Audio Coding(AAC)
MPEG-2 Part 9: Extension for real time interface for system decoders
MPEG-2 Part 10: Conformance extensions for Digital Storage Media Command and Control (DSM-CC)
MPEG-2 Part 11: IPMP on MPEG-2 systems

standardrecord.applicability:
Generic Coding of Moving Pictures and Associated Audio is a formal standard defined by ISO 13818. MPEG-2 is required for generic compression coding of moving pictures and associated audio. MPEG-2 systems will form the infrastructure for delivery of audio and video in many industry sectors, including television distribution, visual telecommunications and a host of computer and multimedia applications.
MPEG-2 was initially intended for the recording and transmission of studio-quality motion video at bit rates in the order of 4 to 6 Mbps. The objective of MPEG-2 is to improve the quality of the image while maintaining the bit rate significantly below 10 Mbps. At the same time, more audio capabilities, such as multiple channels, have been included. The initial MPEG-2 standard has also been extended to support several HDTV formats. Its fields of application should be desktop videoconferencing and videophony

standard.title: Coding of Moving Pictures and Audio (MPEG-4)
MPEG-4 Part 1: Systems
MPEG-4 Part 2: Video
MPEG-4 Part 3: Audio
MPEG-4 Part 4: Conformance Testing
MPEG-4 Part 5: Reference Software
MPEG-4 Part 6: Delivery Multimedia Integration Framework
MPEG-4 Part 7: Optimized reference software for coding of audio-visual objects
MPEG-4 Part 8: Carriage of ISO/IEC 14496 contents over IP networks
MPEG-4 Part 9: Reference hardware description
MPEG-4 Part 10: Advanced Video Coding
MPEG-4 Part 11: Scene description and application engine
MPEG-4 Part 12: ISO base media file format
MPEG-4 Part 13: Intellectual Property Management and Protection (IPMP) extensions
MPEG-4 Part 14: MP4 file format
MPEG-4 Part 15: Advanced Video Coding (AVC) file format
MPEG-4 Part 16: Animation Framework eXtension (AFX)
MPEG-4 Part 17: Streaming text format
MPEG-4 Part 18: Font compression and streaming
MPEG-4 Part 19: Synthesized texture stream
MPEG-4 Part 20: Lightweight Application Scene Representation (LASeR) and Simple Aggregation Format (SAF)
MPEG-4 Part 21: MPEG-J Graphics Framework eXtensions (GFX)
MPEG-4 Part 22: Open Font Format

standardrecord.applicability:
The MPEG-4 standard addresses the coded representation of both natural and synthetic (computer-generated) audio and visual objects. MPEG 4 Systems was developed to provide the necessary facilities for specifying how such objects can be composed together in a MPEG-4 terminal to form complete scenes, as well as how they should be multiplexed for transmission or storage. The term terminal is used here in a generic sense, and of course includes computer programs hosted on general purpose computers.
The fundamental difference to MEG-1 and MPEG-2 systems is that MPEG-4 addresses the coded representation of audiovisual objects, both natural and synthetic. As a result, the Systems layer must address how these objects are composed together to form a scene (composition information or scene description), as well as how a user may interact with such objects. In addition, the object-based architecture necessitates changes in the way audiovisual information is multiplexed. In particular, it has a very flexible multiplexing structure and does not specify a transport layer facility as MPEG-2 did.

standard.title: Coding of moving pictures and associated audio for digital storage media at up to about 1, 5 Mbit/s; PCM Part 3: audio

standardrecord.applicability: Specifies the voice coding e.g. for standard narrowband ISDN telephone systems.

standard.title: DoD Guide to selecting computerbased multi-media standards, technologies, products and practices

standardrecord.applicability: The goal of this document is to provide guidance and to serve as a reference source for information system architects and design engineers, acquisition managers, and procurement officials to select appropriate multimedia standards for their projects. Supporting objectives include enhancing the ease of integration of multimedia products and platforms (often a nontrivial task) and improving interoperability across the DoD enterprise, based on tenets and guidance associated with the Defense Information Infrastructure (DII). This includes conforming to and supporting the relevant standards, technologies, products and practices of the DII Common Operating Environment (COE).

standard.title: Characteristics and Parameters to Assure Black Interoperability between Narrow Band Secure Voice (NBSV) No. 2 and Technical NBSV Type 1 (Draft)

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to define the detailed bit stream characteristics, cryptographic key allocation and distribution methods and system procedures required in the interface between NBSV No. 2 and Tactical NBSV Terminal, Type 1.

standard.title: Single and Multichannel VLF and LF On-Line Broadcast and Off-Line OOK Systems:1995
Voice Coding Algorithm ed.1:1999

standardrecord.applicability:
The aim of this STANAG is to define the technical specifications (standards) to ensure the interoperability of land, air and maritime HF equipment operating in a slow-hop EPM mode.
The transmitting system accepts a continuous data bitstream at 2400 bps from the vocoder system. This data bitstream is the digitally processed voice that has been FEC encoded and interleaved by the vocoder system. Its duration corresponds to each PTT voice input. It is transmitted on the traffic channel without any error-control techniques added by the HF EPM system when EEWF4 is employed.

standard.title: Parameters and Coding Standards for 800 bps Digital Speach Encoder/Decoder

standardrecord.applicability:
The aim of this STANAG is to define:
The voice digitizer characteristics, the coding tables and the bit format requirements at 800 bps;
The error correction scheme and the interleaver to ensure compatability of digital voice produced using an overall bit rate of 2400 bps for slow frequency hopping HF-EPM transmission; and
The End Of Transmission sequence for slow frequency hopping HF-EPM transmission.
The point 1 and the annexes A, B, C, D of the STANAG describe a 800 bps coder useable as a stand alone voice coder in any transmission system needing a low bit rate order.
The points 2 and 3 (and the related annexes F, G, H, I of the STANAG) are specifically aimed at transmission of the afore mentioned coder with the slow frequency hopping HF-EPM waveform.

standard.title: Minimum Technical Equipment Standards For Naval HF Shore-to-Ship Broadcast Systems

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG defines the minimum technical standards for naval shore-to-ship broadcast (shore transmitting and ship receiving) equipment that will permit interoperable communication using HF transmission and appropriate baseband modulation/demodulation techniques.

standard.title: Adaptive coding with embedded dictionary - DCLZ Algorithm

standardrecord.applicability: This standard specifies a lossless compression algorithm, Data Compression according to Lempel and Ziv (DCLZ) to reduce the number of bits required to represent information coded by using 8 bit-bytes. The algorithm is particularly useful when information has to be recorded on an inter-changeable medium. However, its use is not limited to this application.

standard.title: Font information interchange
Font Information Interchange Part 1: Architecture
standard.correction: Multilingual extensions to fnt resource architecture

standard.title: Font Information Interchange Part 2: Interchange Format
Font Information Interchange Part 3: Glyph shape representation

standardrecord.applicability:
This standard, as a whole, specifies the architecture of font resources and the formats for font interchange amongst information processing systems. It also defines the architecture and formats that can be used to construct font references in general electronic document interchange.
Font resources represented using the architecture and interchange formats, as defined in parts 1 and 2, are used in various document-processing environments in which ASN.1 or SGML parsing algorithms are recognised. The encoding of font resource information, as defined in part 3, is specified in both ASN.1 and SGML representations for consistent generation of font resources for use in these processing environments

standard.title: Single UNIX Specification (SUS), Version 2
UNIX 98: Commands and Utilities, Issue 5
UNIX 98: System Interface Definitions, Issue 5
UNIX 98: System Interfaces and Headers, Issue 5
UNIX 98: Networking Services, Issue 5
UNIX 98: X/Open Curses (X Curses), Issue 4 Version 2

standardrecord.applicability: The Commands and Utilities specification (C604) is applicable for systems needing a compression capability. The utilities "compress" and "uncompress" are provided with almost all UNIX implementations, and are readily available for other platforms. Compliance with Version 2 of the SUS is required for the UNIX 98 Brand. See of this volume for a more detailed description of the SUS

standard.title: Standard Interface for Multiple Platform Link Evaluation (SIMPLE)

standardrecord.applicability: The aim of this STANAG is to provide specifications for a common standard to interconnect ground rigs of all types (e.g. simulation, integration facilities etc.) for the purpose of Tactical Data Link (TDL) Interoperability (IOI) testing. The STANAG specifies the distributed transfer using the IEEE Distributed Interactive Simulation (DIS) Application Protocols which are defined in IEEE P1278.1a.

standard.title: NATO Secondary Imagery Format (NSIF)

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG establishes the format for exchange of electronic secondary imagery. Secondary imagery is sensor data that has been previously exploited and/or processed into a human readable picture.This format enables an operator at one workstation to compose and capture a multimedia image on his workstation, and send it to another workstation where it is capable of being reproduced exactly as it was composed on the origination workstation. The NSIF format can be composed of images, graphics and text. Because of the wide variety of display capabilities, the implementations of NSIF readers and writers are classified by their level of complexity, where the highest level will handle very large images with many bands of data, and the simplest level will only handle small, single band images. For interoperability considerations, a reader of an NSIF file must be greater than or equal to the complexity level of the image it is reading in order to display it. There are reserved segments at the end of the NSIF file and within the different segments of the file for other types of information not currently defined in the baseline standard (e.g. GMTI data or motion imagery). For example a reconnaissance exploitation report (RECCEXREP) formatted in an ADatP-3 format could be attached to an image segment through a text segment.

standard.title: NATO Standard Imagery Library Interface (NSILI) ed.3:2010

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG is to provide interoperability between NATO nations reconnaissance databases and product libraries by defining an interoperable interface to each nations? image library systems, without altering the internal architecture each individual system. This STANAG standardizes on the commands that pass back and forth between database systems and the clients as well as the parameters that can be used to search for a particular image in a remote database (e.g. date, time, and location).The interface relies on facilities and services to collaborate database request, reports and orders. The STANAG does not cover the delivery of the requested images to the requestor. It does recommend that products be delivered in STANAG 4545 format.

standard.title: NATO Advanced Data Storage (NADS)

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG defines an interface for advanced digital storage systems, such as solid state memories or disk arrays, with the aim of providing cross servicing capabilities for NATO nations reconnaissance and surveillance assets as well as the exploitation of the imagery data in any reconnaissance ground station. The interface will be a high data rate port to allow direct download of the imagery and auxiliary data, either at the air platform or at the ground station. Once the memory has been transferred to a reconnaissance exploitation ground station, it can be exploited using normal tools.

standard.title: NATO Ground Moving Target Indicator Format (GMTIF)ed.3:2010

standardrecord.applicability: The data format described in this document provides a means for the transmission of Ground Moving Target Indicator (GMTI) detection data. It also offers a format for requesting surveillance service from the sensor and for receiving acknowledgment that the requested surveillance will or will not be performed. The GMTIF is a binary, message-oriented format for the prompt dissemination of MTI data. It may be sent as a stand-alone format or it may be embedded in a frameoriented format, such as the NATO Secondary Imagery Format (NSIF, STANAG 4545) or the National Imagery Transmission Format (NITF, MIL-STD-2500) for the dissemination of secondary imagery, or in a message-oriented format such as the NATO Primary Imagery Format (STANAG 7023) for the dissemination of primary imagery.

standard.title: NATO Digital Motion Imagery Format ed.3:2009

standardrecord.applicability: STANAG 4609 is intended to provide common methods for exchange of across systems within and among NATO nations. STANAG 4609 is intended users a consolidated, clear and concise view of the standards they will operate motion imagery systems. The STANAG includes guidance on compressed, and related motion imagery sampling structures; motion standards, motion imagery metadata standards, interconnections, and language descriptions of motion imagery system parameters. STANAG 4609 that all relevant MI systems used by participating nations will be able compressed data types (Standard Definition, Enhanced Definition, High each Nation may choose to ORIGINATE one, two or all data types. The STANAG 4609 is to provide governance so as to allow participating to meet intelligence, reconnaissance, surveillance and other interoperable MI systems.

standard.title: NATO Primary Imagery Format (NPIF)

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG establishes a standard data format and a standard transport architecture for the transfer of reconnaissance and surveillance imagery and associated auxiliary data between reconnaissance collection systems and exploitation systems. The concept behind STANAG 7023 is to describe the sensor data structure in a space-time domain. This enables STANAG 7023 to describe any sensor data structure without modification to the STANAG. STANAG 7023 is capable of handling any type of sensor. It is simply a shell for capturing multi-source data for the purpose of data correlation at a later time and place. It is also possible from a STANAG 7023 data stream to replicate events in precisely the same order in which they occurred at acquisition.

standard.title: Air Reconnaissance Tape Recorder Interface

standardrecord.applicability:
This STANAG establishes the physical format for the exchange of magnetic tape cartridges for 4 different technologies of recorders. All the recorders in STANAG 7024 are sequential access. The four technologies are each listed in a separate annex as shown below.
Annex A - 19mm helical scan ANSI ID-1 digital instrumentation recorder with large, medium and small tape cartridge formats
Annex B - 8 mm, helical scan Hi-8 digital, and 8mm analogue
Annex C - 12.65 mm helical scan SVHS analogue recorder
Annex D - 25.4 mm transverse scan AMPEX DCRSi digital instrumentation recorder

standard.title: Exchange of Imagery, ed.6

standardrecord.applicability: The purpose of this STANAG is to establish guidelines for the exchange of imagery for use in Imagery Interpretation Keys and to standardise the layout of a form to be used by NATO nations making requests for imagery and related material.

standard.title: Implementing JPEG 2000 in NITFS/BIFF/NSIF (ISO/IEC 10918-4 Annex B)

standardrecord.applicability:
The Basic Image Interchange Format (BIIF) provides a file format that is suitable for the interchange, storage, and retrieval of map and imagery information. The file format consists of a file header and associated image(s), symbol(s), text and/or associated data in a way that is compatible between systems of different architectures and devices of differing capabilities and design.
The BPJ2K01.00 profile defines allowed data values and ranges for JPEG 2000 header and subheader fields contained in an NSIF01.00 file.
The NSIF01.00 profile is designed to promote interoperability for the exchange of digital electronic imagery among multi-national Command, Control, Communications, and Intelligence (C3I) Systems, and those systems needing to interoperate with C3I imagery systems. Adoption by NSIF of JPEG 2000 for compression of digital image data significantly enhances the ability of NSIF to meet its user requirements.

standard.title: Common Data Link

standardrecord.applicability: The CDL is a full duplex, jam resistant point-to-point microwave communication system and intended for use in imagery and signals intelligence collection systems. CDL provides real time connectivity and interoperability between multiple collection platforms and surface terminal. CDL provides a command link up to 200 kb/s and a return link up to 274 Mb/s.

standard.title: Interoperability Standard for the Joint Range Extension Application Protocol (JREAP)
Tactical Data Exchange - Link 11/11B

standardrecord.applicability:
Link-11 employs netted communications techniques and a standard message format for exchanging digital information among airborne, land-based and shipboard tactical data systems. Link-11 data communications must be capable of operation in either the high frequency (HF) or ultrahigh frequency (UHF) bands. When operating in the HF band, Link-11 provides gapless omnidirectional coverage of up to 300 nautical miles (NM) from the transmitting site. When operating in the UHF band, the link provides omnidirectional gapless coverage to approximately 25 NM ship-to-ship, or 150 NM ship-to-air. The messages used to exchange information over Link-11 are known as the M-series messages.
Link-11B employs a dedicated, point-to-point, full duplex digital data link using serial transmission frame characteristics and standard message format for exchanging digital information. Link-11B data is exchanged over a fully automatic, phase-continuous, full duplex, frequency modulated data link operating at a rate of 1200 bps with an alternate capability of 600 bps. Link-11B data communications must be capable of operation in either the UHF or VHF bands.

standard.title: Tactical Data Broadcasting - Link-14

standardrecord.applicability:
Link-14 provides an automatic broadcast of near real-time tactical data from a Tactical Data System (TDS) station to a non-TDS station. This communication link uses standard radio teletype equipment for transmission and reception of tactical data, requiring manual or semi-automatic display by receiving non - TDS unit. The specific operational requirement for Link-14 is to broadcast automatically, selected evaluated target and miscellaneous data on a Radio Teletype (RATT) net to other stations in a task organization.
The Link-14 is a legacy system that most NATO nations have no intention to implement in new platforms other than interfacing data link buffers and have ceased to use or maintain.
In November 2001 the Data Link Working Group (DLWG) approved to discontinue performing configuration management of STANAG 5514. This means that the Link-14 message will no longer be modified.

standard.title: NATO Bit-Oriented Message (BOM) Tactical Data Link

standardrecord.applicability: Link-16 is a high capacity, secure, jam-resistant, nodeless broadcast-type RF data link that uses a Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA) protocol. It provides information distribution, position location, and identification capabilities in an integrated form for tactical military operations. Link-16 utilises the Joint Tactical Information Distribution System (JTIDS) or the Multi-Functional Information Distribution System (MIDS) terminals, and the protocols, conventions, and fixed word message formats defined by STANAG 5516. JTIDS/MIDS operates in the upper ultra high frequency Lx band.

standard.title: Link-22

standardrecord.applicability: Link-22 is important for long distance communication and is planned to replace Link-11 in the future and to be used during some period in parallel with Link-11. Link-22 Transmission media will be used to exchange Link-22 messages. Link-22 messages, comprised of F-Series formats, will be used for the exchange of maritime operational data between tactical data systems using line of sight (UHF) and beyond line of sight (HF) bands. The standard for Link-22 waveform is under development.

standard.title: National Imagery Transmission Format Standard, v2.1

standardrecord.applicability: The initial NITFS purpose was to standardize the imagery format and associated data being transmitted from/to secondary imagery dissemination systems (SIDS). Due to the growing NITFS acceptance, it is now being applied to imagery dissemination systems in general, not SIDS alone. The purpose of NITFS is to transmit a file composed of an image accompanied by subimages, symbols, labels, text, and other information that relate to the image. One of the main features of the NITFS is that it allows several items of each data type to be included in one file, yet any data types may be omitted. The NITF file incorporates the CGM standard for graphics and accommodates user-selectable compression for images. The file is submitted to the Message Transfer Facility (MXF), which allows it to be transferred using any of a set of user-selectable protocols and media. The output is a message which, by conforming to the standards and their use, is compliant with the NITFS.

standard.title: Interoperable Data Links for Imaging Systems

standardrecord.applicability: This STANAG provide the interoperability standards for 3 classes of imagery DL used for primary imagery data transmission: analogue links described in Annex A, point-to-point digital links described in Annex B and broadcast digital links described in Annex C. Command and control of the sensors and platform is an auxiliary mission. Annex B is organized in 2 chapters: General Requirements and Implementation Directives, which describe point-to-point digital links. Different implementation profiles are possible : the U.S. Common Data Link (CDL) is described in Implementation 1. Further study continues to update the Annex C Digital Broadcast configuration. The STANAG is structured such that it provides a number of options for the specific data link configuration, such as simplex or duplex operation, data rate, carrier frequency, channel multiplexing, interleaving, encryption, and many others that must be matched prior to passing data from transmitter to receiver. STANAG 7085 data links can handle any form of data (e.g. 7023, 4545, or GMTI), and can operate in different configurations, including two way (half or full duplex) modes.

standard.title: Standard Interfaces of UAV Control System (UCS) for NATO UAV Interoperability

standardrecord.applicability: The objective of this STANAG is to facilitate communication between a UCS and different UAVs and their payloads as well as multiple C4I users. The implementation of the standard UCS architecture and the interfaces will also ease the system integration process of subsystems from different sources. This standardization will allow the continued utilisation and the integration of legacy systems. This STANAG is under the control of the NATO Naval Armaments Group (NNAG).

standard.title: Document Object Model (DOM) Level 2 Core Specification
Document Object Model (DOM) Level 2 Events Specification
Document Object Model (DOM) Level 2 Style Specification
Document Object Model (DOM) Level 2 Traversal and Range Specification
Document Object Model (DOM) Level 2 Views Specification

profilerecord.applicability:
The specification defines the Document Object Model Level 2 HTML, a platform- and language-neutral interface that allows programs and scripts to dynamically access and update the content and structure of HTML 4.01 and XHTML 1.0 documents. The Document Object Model Level 2 HTML builds on the Document Object Model Level 2 Core and is not backward compatible with DOM Level 1 HTML. The goals of the HTML-specific DOM API are:
(1) to specialize and add functionality that relates specifically to HTML documents and elements.
(2) to address issues of backwards compatibility with the DOM Level 0.
(3) to provide convenience mechanisms, where appropriate, for common and frequent operations on HTML documents.
The key differences between the core DOM and the HTML application of DOM is that the HTML Document Object Model exposes a number of convenience methods and properties that are consistent with the existing models and are more appropriate to script writers. In many cases, these enhancements are not applicable to a general DOM because they rely on the presence of a predefined DTD. The transitional or frameset DTD for HTML 4.01, or the XHTML 1.0 DTDs are assumed. Interoperability between implementations is only guaranteed for elements and attributes that are specified in the HTML 4.01 and XHTML 1.0 DTDs.

standard.title: Document Object Model (DOM) Level 3 Core Specification
Document Object Model (DOM) Level 3 Load and Save Specification
Document Object Model (DOM) Level 3 Validation Specification

profilerecord.applicability:
This specification defines the Document Object Model Core Level 3, a platform- and language-neutral interface that allows programs and scripts to dynamically access and update the content, structure and style of documents. The Document Object Model Core Level 3 builds on the Document Object Model Core Level 2 [DOM Level 2 Core].
This version enhances DOM Level 2 Core by completing the mapping between DOM and the XML Information Set [XML Information Set], including the support for XML Base [XML Base], adding the ability to attach user information to DOM Nodes or to bootstrap a DOM implementation, providing mechanisms to resolve namespace prefixes or to manipulate "ID" attributes, giving to type information, etc.

standard.title: Directory Service Markup Language v2:2002

standardrecord.applicability:
DSML is a way to access (i.e. query and update) LDAP directory information as XML documents:
DSML is an XML schema
The DSML grammar follows the same rules as LDAP?s ASN.1 grammar
DSML is not an access protocol, but it depends on an access protocol to wor
DSML performs LDAP operations towards the LDAP directory
It is implemented as an ISAPI extention on the IIS Web-server
DSML bindings:
DSMLv2 defines two normative types of bindings
SOAP Request/Response Binding
Uses HTTP as the transport for DSML requests/responses
Authentication is dependent on the transport
SOAP messages contain DSML payloads
File Binding
Serves as the DSML equivalent of LDAP Data Interchange Format (LDIF)
DSML ?server? is a Command-line program
Authenticates to the directory using the user identity with which the command-line program was invoked.
Other DSMLv2 bindings may be developed given that they meet certain requirements
DSML usage:
Provides easy access to directories from within standard Web/XML application development environments
Allows communication across firewalls that don?t allow LDAP traffic, but that can pass HTTP/XML
Possible to access the directory from clients that don?t contain an LDAP client (e.g. cell phones, PDAs)
In short, DSML extends the reach of directories

standard.title: Document Style Semantics and Specification Language (DSSSL)

standardrecord.applicability: DSSSL defines the semantics and syntax of a language for the specification of document processing. The semantics include a document architecture for typographic presentation style and other document processing specifications typically associated with traditional text processing languages. It is designed to specify the processing of documents conforming to SGML for their presentation.

standard.title: electronic business eXtensible Markup Language (ebXML) Technical Architecture Specification v1.0.4

standardrecord.applicability: ebXML, sponsored by UN/CEFACT and OASIS, is a modular suite of specifications that enables enterprises of any size and in any geographical location to conduct business over the Internet. Using ebXML, companies now have a standard method to exchange business messages, conduct trading relationships, communicate data in common terms and define and register business processes.

standard.title: Efficient XML Interchange Format (EXI) v1.0

standardrecord.applicability: This document is the specification of the Efficient XML Interchange (EXI) format. EXI is a very compact representation for the eXtensible Markup Language (XML) Information Set that is intended to simultaneously optimize performance and the utilization of computational resources. The EXI format uses a hybrid approach drawn from the information and formal language theories, plus practical techniques verified by measurements, for entropy encoding XML information. Using a relatively simple algorithm, which is amenable to fast and compact implementation, and a small set of data types, it reliably produces efficient encodings of XML event streams. The event production system and format definition of EXI are presented.

standard.title: HyperText Markup Language (HTML), Version 4.0.1, Reference Specification

standardrecord.applicability: The HyperText Markup Language (HTML) is a simple markup language used to create hypertext documents that are portable from one platform to another. HTML documents are SGML documents with generic semantics that are appropriate for representing information from a wide range of applications. HTML 3.2 is an SGML application conforming to International Standard ISO 8879 - Standard Generalised Markup Language. As an SGML application, the syntax of conforming HTML documents is defined by the combination of the SGML declaration and the document type definition (DTD). This specification defines the intended interpretation of HTML elements, and places further constraints on the permitted syntax which are otherwise inexpressible in the DTD.

standard.title: Coding of Multimedia and Hypermedia Information, Multimedia and Hypermedia information coding Expert Group (MHEG)
MHEG Part 1: MHEG object representation, Base Notation (ASN.1)
MHEG Part 3: MHEG script interchange representation
MHEG Part 4: MHEG registration procedure
MHEG Part 5: Support for base-level interactive applications
MHEG Part 6: Support for enhanced interactive applications
MHEG Part 7: Interoperability and conformance testing for ISO/IEC
MHEG Part 8: XML notation for ISO/IEC

standardrecord.applicability: MHEG will offer a generic tool for interchange of multimedia information through telecommunication networks or by the means of digital storage medium. It will provide facilities to represent and encode multimedia synchronisation and hyperlinks, while taking into account real time and interchange requirements. MHEG is developed according to “object oriented” concepts

standard.title: Microsoft Office 2000

standardrecord.applicability: MS Office 2000 incorporates MS Word word-processing, Excel spreadsheet, PowerPoint presentation slides tool and Access database. Formats of these products can be imported and exported into other products

standard.title: Microsoft Office XP

standardrecord.applicability: MS Office XP incorporates MS Word word-processing, Excel spreadsheet, PowerPoint presentation slides tool and Access database. Formats of these products can be imported and exported into other products

standard.title: Microsoft Office 2003

standardrecord.applicability: MS Office 2003 incorporates MS Word word-processing, Excel spreadsheet, PowerPoint presentation slides tool and Access database. Formats of these products can be imported and exported into other products

standard.title: Namespaces in XML

standardrecord.applicability: XML namespaces provide a simple method for qualifying element and attribute names used in Extensible Markup Language documents by associating them with namespaces identified by URI references.

profilerecord.profilenote: Information Processing - Text and Office Systems, Office Document Architecture (ODA) and Interchange Format (ISO/IEC 8613)

standard.title: ODA Part 1: Introduction and General Principles
ODA Part 2: Document Structures
ODA Part 3: Abstract Interface for Manipulation of ODA Documents
ODA Part 4: Document Profile
ODA Part 5: Office Document Interchange Format (ODIF)
ODA Part 6: Character Content Architectures
ODA Part 7: Raster Graphics Content Architectures
ODA Part 8: Geometric Graphics Content Architectures
ODA Part 9: Audio Content Architectures
ODA Part 10: Formal Specifications
ODA Part 11: ODA Tabular Structures and Tabular Layouts
ODA Part 12: ODA Identification of Document Fragments
ODA Part 14: Temporal relationships and non-linear structures

profilerecord.applicability:
This standard permits the interchange of documents between co-operating tools in office systems by providing a common understanding of the structure of documents. For the ODA standard, a document is a structured amount of text, graphics, and scanned images, is characterised by its content (logical structure) and its internal organisation (layout structure), and can be grouped into a document class getting together similar documents such as report, letter, memo.
Part 5 (ODIF) is an ASN.1 based presentation, which specifies the interchange format for ODA documents.
Office Document Language (ODL) is the Standard Generalised Mark-up Language (SGML) encoding for ODA documents to enter an SGML database or publishing environment

standard.title: Open Document Format (ODF) for Office Applications (OpenDocument) v1.0

standardrecord.applicability:
This document defines an XML schema for office applications and its semantics. The schema is suitable for office documents, including text documents, spreadsheets, charts and graphical documents like drawings or presentations, but is not restricted to these kinds of documents.
The schema provides for high-level information suitable for editing documents. It defines suitable XML structures for office documents and is friendly to transformations using XSLT or similar XML-based tools.

standard.title: Office Open XML file formats

standardrecord.applicability: ISO/IEC 29500 is a standard for word-processing documents, presentations and spreadsheets that is intended to be implemented by multiple applications on multiple platforms. According to the submitters of the document, one of its objectives is to ensure the long-term preservation of documents created over the last two decades using programmes that are becoming incompatible with continuing advances in the field of information technology.

standard.title: Portable Document Format (PDF), v. 1.4

standardrecord.applicability: PDF is a file format used to represent a document in final form independent of the application software, hardware, and operating system used to create it. It offers precise control over the documents appearance and permits the document to retain that same appearance over different platforms. The document may contain any combination of text, graphics, and images in a device independent and resolution independent form. It may also contain information possible only in an electronic representation, e.g. a set of hot links, thumbnail icons of pages, chapter outlines and page annotations. The PDF file contents may be searched and archived

standard.title: PostScript Level 1(1985), Level 2 (1990), Level 3 (1995)

standardrecord.applicability: PostScript is a page description language for printing and displaying documents that integrate text, graphics, images, and colour. It works seamlessly with every major operating system and colour management systems. Adobe's "PostScript Language Reference Manual", Third Edition, 1999, describes the actual status of this language.

standard.title: RELAX NG Specification
RELAX NG Tutorial
RELAX NG Compact Syntax
Guidelines for using W3C XML Schema Datatypes with RELAX NG
RELAX NG DTD Compatibility

profilerecord.applicability:
RELAX NG is a simple schema language for XML, based on [RELAX] and [TREX]. A RELAX NG schema specifies a pattern for the structure and content of an XML document. A RELAX NG schema is itself an XML document.
RELAX NG deals with XML documents representing both schemas and instances through an abstract data model. XML documents representing schemas and instances must be well-formed in conformance with [XML 1.0] and must conform to the constraints of [XML Namespaces].

standard.title: Rich Text Format (RTF), Version 1.5

standardrecord.applicability: Rich Text Format (RTF) is a text document formatting language. It provides a neutral format for the interchange of textual documents between computer platforms. Word processing documents, which are saved in RTF format, for the purpose of interchange, are able to retain more of their original structure and format (e.g. simple tables) than documents saved as plain text only. RTF may be used to transfer word processing documents between heterogeneous WP systems and preserve much of the original format. Full word processing document/events can be considerably larger than their text equivalents and RTF may be a good compromise in a low bandwidth environment

profilerecord.profilenote: Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) v1.1

standard.title: SAML Assertions and Protocol v.2.2
SAML Bindings and Profiles
SAML Security and Privacy Considerations
SAML Conformance Program Specification
SAML Glossary
SAML Assertion Schema
SAML Protocol Schema

profilerecord.applicability: The Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) standard defines a framework for exchanging security information between online business partners

standard.title: XML Encryption Syntax and Processing:2008

standardrecord.applicability: This document specifies a process for encrypting data and representing the result in XML. The data may be arbitrary data (including an XML document), an XML element, or XML element content. The result of encrypting data is an XML Encryption element which contains or references the cipher data.

standard.title: XML Signature Syntax and Processing (2nd ed.):2008

standardrecord.applicability: This document specifies XML digital signature processing rules and syntax. XML Signatures provide integrity, message authentication, and/or signer authentication services for data of any type, whether located within the XML that includes the signature or elsewhere.

standard.title: XML Key Management Specification:2001

standardrecord.applicability: This document specifies protocols for distributing and registering public keys, suitable for use in conjunction with the proposed standard for XML Signature [XML-SIG] developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) and the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) and an anticipated companion standard for XML encryption. The XML Key Management Specification (XKMS) comprises two parts -- the XML Key Information Service Specification (X-KISS) and the XML Key Registration Service Specification (X-KRSS).

profilerecord.profilenote: eXtensible Access Control Markup Language (XACML) Version 2.0

standard.title: eXtensible Access Control Markup Language core specification v2.0:2008
Core and hierarchical role based access control (RBAC) profile of XACML v2.0
Hierarchical resource profile of XACML v2.0
Multiple resource profile of XACML v2.0
Privacy policy profile of XACML v2.0
SAML 2.0 profile of XACML v2.0
XML Digital Signature profile of XACML v2.0

profilerecord.applicability: The security policy of a large enterprise has many elements and many points of enforcement. Elements of policy may be managed by the Information Systems department, by Human Resources, by the Legal department and by the Finance department. And the policy may be enforced by the extranet, mail, WAN and remote-access systems; platforms which inherently implement a permissive security policy. The current practice is to manage the configuration of each point of enforcement independently in order to implement the security policy as accurately as possible. Consequently, it is an expensive and unreliable proposition to modify the security policy. And, it is virtually impossible to obtain a consolidated view of the safeguards in effect throughout the enterprise to enforce the policy. At the same time, there is increasing pressure on corporate and government executives from consumers, shareholders and regulators to demonstrate "best practice" in the protection of the information assets of the enterprise and its customers. For these reasons, there is a pressing need for a common language for expressing security policy. If implemented throughout an enterprise, a common policy language allows the enterprise to manage the enforcement of all the elements of its security policy in all the components of its information systems. Managing security policy may include some or all of the following steps: writing, reviewing, testing, approving, issuing, combining, analyzing, modifying, withdrawing, retrieving and enforcing policy. XML is a natural choice as the basis for the common security-policy language, due to the ease with which its syntax and semantics can be extended to accommodate the unique requirements of this application, and the widespread support that it enjoys from all the main platform and tool vendors.

standard.title: Simple API for XML (SAX 2.0.1)

standardrecord.applicability: SAX2 is the dominant API for efficient XML processing with Java. With the SAX2 API, developers have access to the information in XML documents as they are read, without imposing major memory constraints or a large code footprint. SAX2 is often used by other APIs "under the covers", and provides a foundation for processing and creating both XML and non-XML information.

standard.title: Standard Generalised Mark-up Language (SGML)

standardrecord.applicability: SGML is a mark-up language for defining the logical structure of documents. SGML is capable of supporting the integration of text, graphics and scanned images. SGML permits a document to be broken down into parts which can be stored in several files. It is characterised by its content (logical structure) and its internal organisation (layout structure) which are derived from a formal type by means of what is known as a Document Type Definition (DTD).

standard.title: Symbolic Link Format (SYLK)

standardrecord.applicability: SYLK is a basic spreadsheet interchange format that can be used to import/export spreadsheet information into other products that support the SYLK format

standard.title: Wireless Markup Language (WML) version 2
