PEX supports nearly all the features found in PHIGS and PHIGS Plus. A primary advantage of PEX is interoperability, allowing users to execute applications on one vendor's machine, while simultaneously displaying the 3-D graphical output on a second vendor's platform

status.info: PEXlib Reference Manual ISBN 1-56592-029-5, and PEXlib Programming Manual ISBN 1-56592-028-7.

standard.title: Programmer's Hierarchical Interactive Graphics System
PHIGS Part 1: Functional description
PHIGS Part 2: Archive file format
PHIGS Part 3: Specification for clear-text encoding of archive file

standardrecord.applicability: This specification fulfils the requirement for a language to program 2- and 3-dimensional graphical objects that will be displayed or plotted on appropriate devices in interactive, high performance environments, and for managing hierarchical database structures containing graphics data

standard.title: Unified Modeling Language, v2.0:2010

standardrecord.applicability: The Unified Modeling Language (UML) is a graphical language for visualizing, specifying, constructing, and documenting the artifacts of a software-intensive system. The UML offers a standard way to write a system's blueprints, including conceptual things such as business processes and system functions as well as concrete things such as programming language statements, database schemas, and reusable software components.

standard.title: X Window System Image Extension (XIE), v.5.02

standardrecord.applicability: The X Image Extension provides a mechanism for the transfer and display of virtually any image on any X-capable hardware. This version of XIE also contains a subset which is called the DIS or the Document Imaging Subset.

status.info: More information in X Image Extension Protocol Reference Manual and other XIE and XIElib info, to be reached on the Internet

standard.title: Standardised Coded Graphic Character Sets for Use in 8-bit Codes

standardrecord.applicability: This standard specifies a unique coded graphic character set for 8-bit codes. It includes as a reference the specific language codings in ISO 8859. The only character set in ISO/IEC 10367 that is not also included in one of the ISO 8859 parts is a character set for drawing box figures.

standard.title: Conversion Between the Two Coded Character Sets of ISO/IEC 646 and ISO/IEC 6937:1994 and the CCITT International Telegraph Alphabet (ITA) No. 2

standardrecord.applicability: This standard specifies the rules for conversion between ITA 2 representation of 58 characters and the ISO/IEC 646 representation of 128 characters.

standard.title: ISO 7-Bit and 8-Bit Coded Character Sets - Control Functions for Coded Character Sets

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines control functions and their coded representations for use in a 7-bit code, an extended 7-bit code, and 8-bit code, or and extended 8-bit code.

standard.title: Codes for the representation of names of countries and their subdivisions
ISO Country Codes
ISO Subdivision Codes
ISO Codes for formerly used names of countries

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines a 2-letter, a 3-letter and a numeric code for each country on this planet.

standard.title: Codes for the Representation of Currencies and Funds

standardrecord.applicability: This standard specifies the representation of currencies and currency symbols.

standard.title: Representation of Dates and Times

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines formats for numerical representation of dates, times and date/time combinations. It is applicable whenever dates and times are included in information interchange. Local time and Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) are supported. Dates are for the Gregorian calendar and can be given in year-month-day, year-week-day or year-day formats. Times are given in 24hr format. Characters are taken from ISO/IEC 646.

standard.title: Representation of Human Sexes

standardrecord.applicability: This standard specifies a uniform representation of human sexes for the interchange of information.

standard.title: Representation of Latitude, Longitude and Altitude of Geographic Positions

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines the representation of latitude, longitude, and altitude of geographic positions.

standard.title: Code for the Representation of Names of Languages
Representation of Names of Languages Part 2: Alpha-3

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines the codes representing the names of languages as two-letter lower-case symbols.

standard.title: Letters for Geographic Entities, ed.8:2005
standard.comment: A NATO standard of codes for distinguishing geographical entities, nations and countries.

standard.title: Presentation of Numerical Values in Character Strings for Information Interchange

standardrecord.applicability: This standard specifies three presentations of numerical values, which are represented in character strings in a form readable by machine, for use in interchange between data processing systems. It also provides guidance for developers of programming language standards and implementers of programming products. These representations are recognisable by humans and thus may be useful in communications between humans as well.

standard.title: Keyboard Layouts for Text and Office Systems
Keyboard Layouts Part 1: General principles governing keyboard layouts
Keyboard Layouts Part 2: Alphanumeric section
Keyboard Layouts Part 3: Complementary layouts of the alphanumeric zone of the alphanumeric section
Keyboard Layouts Part 4: Numeric section
Keyboard Layouts Part 5: Editing section
Keyboard Layouts Part 6: Function section
Keyboard Layouts Part 7: Symbols used to represent functions
Keyboard Layouts Part 8: Allocation of letters to the keys of a numeric keypad

standardrecord.applicability: This family of eight standards defines the layout of keyboards so that they can be used for input of multilingual information.

standard.title: Registration of repertoires of graphic characters from ISO/IEC 10367

standardrecord.applicability: This standard specifies the procedures for preparing, registering, publishing, and maintaining the register of graphic character sets that are composed from the character repertoire of ISO/IEC 6937 and the procedures for assigning identifiers to the sets.

standard.title: Ada

standardrecord.applicability: Ada is a general purpose high-order object-oriented programming language capable of processing both numerical and textual data that has the key attributes of strong data typing, data abstraction, object-orientation, structured constructs, multitasking and concurrent processing. For R&D it is encouraged to use Ada95

standard.title: Ada Semantic Interface Specification (ASIS)

standardrecord.applicability: ASIS is a programmatic interface between an Ada compiler's library database and any tool or program requiring information from this library. ASIS provides access to both the syntactic and semantic information contained in an Ada compiler library

history.event: ASIS is now an official ISO/IEC standard

standard.title: Programming Language C

standardrecord.applicability: C is a general purpose high-order programming language designed for use in systems programming.

standard.title: Programming Language C++

standardrecord.applicability: C++ is the object-oriented version of the C language and as such is much richer in its functionality. It may be used in environments where interoperability with COTS components developed in C or C++ is required

standard.title: C# Language Specification, 2nd edition

standardrecord.applicability: C# is a modern, object-oriented language that enables programmers to quickly build a wide range of applications for the new Microsoft .NET development environment, which provides tools and services that fully exploit both computing and communications. Because of its elegant object-oriented design, C# is a great choice for architecting a wide range of components-from high-level business objects to system-level applications. Using simple C# language constructs, these components can be converted into XML Web services, allowing them to be invoked across the Internet, from any language running on any operating system.

standard.title: ECMAScript Language Specification ed.3:2009

standardrecord.applicability:
ECMAScript (originally known as JavaScript before it became an open standard) is used to deliver enhanced web page features. It is supported by most common web browsers.
ECMAScript is an object-oriented programming language for performing computations and manipulating computational objects within a host environment. ECMAScript is not intended to be computationally self-sufficient; indeed, there are no provisions in this specification for input of external data or output of computed results. Instead, it is expected that the computational environment of an ECMAScript program will provide not only the objects and other facilities described in this specification but also certain environment- specific host objects, whose description and behaviour arebeyond the scope of this specification except to indicate that they may provide certain properties that can be accessed and certain functions that can be called from an ECMAScript program.

standard.title: Java programming language

standardrecord.applicability: Java is a general purpose high-order object-oriented programming language designed for use in programming on multi-platform targeted applications, such as net-distributed software. The use of Java may be recommended to develop applets

status.info: SUN applied for a Public Available Specification (PAS) ISO standardisation procedure.

standard.title: Hypertext Preprocessor

standardrecord.applicability: PHP is a widely-used Open Source general purpose scripting language that is especially suited for Web development and can be embedded into HTML. Its syntax draws upon C, Java, and Perl. The main goal of the language is to allow web developers to write dynamically generated webpages quickly.

profilerecord.profilenote: Electronic Industries Association (EIA) CASE Data Interchange Format (CDIF),
Note: EIA/IS = EIA Interim Standard.

standard.title: CDIF - CASE Data Interchange Format - Overview
CDIF - Framework for Modelling and Extensibility
CDIF - Transfer Format/General Rules for Syntaxes and Encodings
CDIF - Transfer Format/Syntax SYNTAX.1
CDIF - Transfer Format/Encoding ENCODING.1
CDIF - Transfer Format/XML-based transfer format
CDIF - Transfer Format/OMG IDL bindings
CDIF - Integrated CASE Meta-model/Foundation Subject Area
CDIF - Integrated CASE Meta-model/Common Subject Area
CDIF - Integrated CASE Meta-model/Data Modelling Subject Area
CDIF - Integrated CASE Meta-model/Data Flow Model Subject Area
CDIF - Integrated CASE Meta-model/Presentation Location and Connectivity Subject Area

profilerecord.applicability: The CDIF family of standards is primarily designed as a data interchange format to serve as a standard for the exchange of information between CASE tools. It assumes that two or more tools may interface asynchronously with each other and will transfer information from one to another via “CDIF files.” The type of information that may be contained in these files is defined by the CDIF conceptual models.

standard.title: NATO Quality Control Requirements for Design, Development and Production, edition 2

standardrecord.applicability: The majority of the AQAP series are based on the ISO9000 series documents. The requirements section of the AQAPs are a direct reflection of those found in the ISO. NATO supplements are added to those ISO clauses where further clarification or added requirements are necessary

standard.title: NATO Quality Assurance Requirements for Software Development, edition 2

standardrecord.applicability: This document specifies the requirements in managing the quality of software processes

standard.title: EIA Standard, National consensus standard for configuration management

standardrecord.applicability: This standard presents configuration management and discusses practices from an enterprise view; it does not mandate them. The principles are selectively applicable to a broad range of customers, products and industries. This standard is not intended for use as a compliance document or an evaluation mechanism; rather it is intended for use as a source document for either purpose

standard.title: Software Life Cycle Processes - Software Development, Acquirer-Supplier Agreement

standardrecord.applicability: The requirements in this standard are intended for application to the development of systems that contain software, to systems consisting of software alone, to stand-alone software products, and to software services. It can be used as a basis for an organisation's software development process, and can be applied to contractors, subcontractors or in-house development

standard.title: Quality Systems - Model for Quality Assurance in Design, Development, Production, Installation and Servicing

standardrecord.applicability: This norm specifies requirements in design, development, production, installation and servicing for a quality system when the ability of a supplier to deliver a product in conformance needs to be demonstrated

standard.title: Quality Management and Quality System Elements: Guidelines for performance improvements
Guidelines for quality plans
Guidelines to quality in project management
Guidelines for configuration management

profilerecord.applicability: This norm specifies requirements in final inspection and testing for a quality system when the ability of a supplier to deliver a product in conformance needs to be demonstrated

standard.title: Software engineering - Product Quality - Part 1: Quality model

standardrecord.applicability: This norm defines 6 characteristics describing software quality in order to evaluate software products (functionality, reliability, usability, efficiency, maintainability, portability)

standard.title: Software Life Cycle Processes

standardrecord.applicability: This standard applies to the acquisition of systems and software products and to the supply, development, operation and maintenance of software products. It is intended for use in a two-party situation

standard.title: Software Product Evaluation
Software Product Evaluation Part 1: General overview
Software Product Evaluation Part 2: Planning and management
Software Product Evaluation Part 3: Process for developer's
Software Product Evaluation Part 4: Process for acquirers
Software Product Evaluation Part 5: Process for evaluator's
Software Product Evaluation Part 6: Documentation of evaluation modules

standardrecord.applicability: ISO 14598 defines product evaluation processes that clearly establish testing as a major activity that must be specified, planned, managed and executed, not just as a quick afterthought at the end of the software development life cycle.

standard.title: Guidelines for auditing quality systems

standardrecord.applicability: This norm specifies guidelines to organise, planify, lead and document audits of quality systems, criteria for auditor qualification and guidelines to manage audit programs.

standard.title: Software Process Assessment
Software Process Assessment Part 1: Concepts and introductory guide (informative)
Software Process Assessment Part 2: A reference model for processes and process capability (normative)
Software Process Assessment Part 3: Performing an assessment (normative)
Software Process Assessment Part 4: Guide to performing assessments (informative)
Software Process Assessment Part 5: An assessment model and indicator guidance (informative)
Software Process Assessment Part 6: Guide to qualification of assessors (informative)
Software Process Assessment Part 7: Guide for use in process improvement (informative)
Software Process Assessment Part 8: Guide for use in determining supplier process capability (informative)
Software Process Assessment Part 9: Vocabulary (informative)

standardrecord.applicability: This standard provides a framework for the assessment of software processes. This framework can be used by organisations involved in planning, managing, monitoring, controlling, and improving the acquisition, supply, development, operation, evolution and support of software

standard.title: Software Life Cycle Process, Part 2: Configuration management for software

standardrecord.applicability: This standard defines the requirements for performance of the software configuration management process in a 2 party or joint-venture contract. The standard is applicable to any class or type of software products, to the entire software product life-cycle, to software acquired from a subcontractor or vendor applying or not configuration management, the supplier and the acquirer of the software product

standard.title: Materiel Configuration Management Policy and Procedures for Multinational Joint Projects, edition 2

standardrecord.applicability: This document describes configuration management procedures to be applied to all elements of a system (hardware, software and associated documentation)

standard.title: NATO Policy Guidance for the Utilisation of Simulation, Prototyping and Testing in the Development and Acquisition of Complex Software Based Systems

standardrecord.applicability: AC/317-D/42 is to provide guidance to policy authorities and approving authorities in the requirements, technical, financial and contracting areas, users, system managers and implementers, and host nations and procurement agencies in the features of testbeds, simulators and prototypes, their use in terms of functionality and project phasing

standard.title: NATO Software Management Policy, Edition 1

standardrecord.applicability: AC/317-D/70 is to state the authoritative NATO Software Management Policy, which shall be adhered to when planning, implementing, operating and maintaining any future NATO funded software based system

standard.title: Compress

standardrecord.applicability: The compress utility will attempt to reduce the size of the named files by using adaptive Lempel-Ziv coding.

standard.title: Tape Archiver

standardrecord.applicability:
The tar program provides the ability to create tar archives, as well as various other kinds of manipulation. For example, you can use tar on previously created archives to extract files, to store additional files, or to update or list files which were already stored.
Initially, tar archives were used to store files conveniently on magnetic tape. The name `tar' comes from this use; it stands for tape archiver. Despite the utility's name, tar can direct its output to available devices, files, or other programs (using pipes). tar may even access remote devices or files (as archives).

standard.title: DEFLATE Compressed Data Format Specification version 1.3
GZIP file format specification version 4.3

profilerecord.applicability: An open standard for compression and decompression used widely for PC download archives, ZIP was developed by Phil Katz for his DOS-based program PKZip, and it is is now widely used on Windows-based programs such as WinZip and Drag and Zip. The file extension given to ZIP files is .zip.

standard.title: ISO 7-Bit Coded Character Set for Information Interchange

standardrecord.applicability:
This standard defines the binary representation of 128 control, (Latin) alphabet, digit, and symbol characters. It describes in general the use of the control characters and describes the option of national replacement characters.
Supports the English languages and some other Latin-based non-English languages. Supported by most IT products.

standard.title: 8-Bit Single Byte Coded Graphic Character Sets, Parts 1-15
standard.comment: The ten parts address the following languages:

standard.title: 8-Bit Code Set Part 1: Latin Alphabet No. 1 (Europe/Latin America)
8-Bit Code Set Part 2: Latin Alphabet No. 2 (Eastern Europe)
8-Bit Code Set Part 3: Latin Alphabet No. 3 (SE Europe)
8-Bit Code Set Part 4: Latin Alphabet No. 4 (Scandinavia/Baltic)
8-Bit Code Set Part 5: Latin/Cyrillic Alphabet
8-Bit Code Set Part 6: Latin/Arabic Alphabet
8-Bit Code Set Part 7: Latin/Greek Alphabet
8-Bit Code Set Part 8: Latin/Hebrew Alphabet
8-Bit Code Set Part 9: Latin Alphabet No. 5
8-Bit Code Set Part 10: Latin Alphabet No. 6
8-Bit Code Set Part 13: Latin alphabet No. 7
8-Bit Code Set Part 14: Latin alphabet No. 8 (Celtic)
8-Bit Code Set Part 15: Latin alphabet No. 9
8-Bit Code Set Part 16: Latin alphabet No. 10

standardrecord.applicability:
This standard specifies a set of up to 191 graphic characters by means of a single 8-Bit byte.
The ISO 8859 charsets were designed in the mid-1980s by the European Computer Manufacturer's Association (ECMA) and endorsed by the International Standards Organisation (ISO).The ISO 8859 charsets are not even remotely as complete as the truly great Unicode but they have been around and usable for quite a while (first registered Internet charsets for use with MIME) and have already offered a major improvement over the plain 7bit US-ASCII.

standard.title: Information Technology - Universal Multiple-Octet Coded Character Set (UCS)

standardrecord.applicability:
For environments requiring an extended character set (see also UNICODE).
This standard is intended to define the presentation of all scripts of the world in computer-based systems and their unambiguous interchange between one system or person and another. It is applicable to the representation, processing, storage, and presentation of the written form of the languages of the world.
Note: ISO/IEC 10646 and ISO/IEC 646 make consistent code assignments for characters that are supported by ISO/IEC 646.
It is unlikely that support for more than two-octet encoding will be required.

standard.title: UTF-8, a transformation format of ISO/IEC 10646
Policy on Character Sets and Languages

profilerecord.applicability:
RFC 2277:1998 mandates support of RFC 2279:1998 on the Internet.
UTF-8 uses all 8 bits of an octet, but has the quality of preserving the full US-ASCII backward compatibility.

profilerecord.profilenote: The Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME)

standard.title: MIME - Part 1: Format of Internet Message Bodies
MIME - Part 2: Media Types
MIME - Part 3: Message Header Extensions for Non-ASCII Text
MIME - Part 4: Registration Procedures
MIME - Part 5: Conformance Criteria and Examples

profilerecord.applicability: RFC 822:1982 defines a message representation protocol specifying considerable detail about US-ASCII message headers, and leaves the message content, or message body, as flat US-ASCII text. This set of documents, collectively called the Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions, or MIME, redefines the format of messages to allow for (1) textual message bodies in character sets other than US-ASCII, (2) an extensible set of different formats for non-textual message bodies, (3) multi-part message bodies, and (4) textual header information in character sets other than US-ASCII. Because RFC 822:1982 said so little about message bodies, these documents are largely orthogonal to (rather than a revision of) RFC 822:1982. The initial document (RFC 2045:1996) specifies the various headers used to describe the structure of MIME messages. The second document, RFC 2046:1996, defines the general structure of the MIME media typing system and defines an initial set of media types. The third document, RFC 2047:1996, describes extensions to RFC 822:1982 to allow non-US-ASCII text data in Internet mail header fields. The fourth document, RFC 2048:1996, specifies various IANA registration procedures for MIME-related facilities. The fifth and final document, RFC 2049:1996, describes MIME conformance criteria as well as providing some illustrative examples of MIME message formats, acknowledgements, and the bibliography.

standard.title: UUENCODE

standardrecord.applicability: uuencode translates a binary file into a special code that consists entirely of printable characters. A file encoded in this way is generally safe for transmission over networks and phone lines. uuencode is often used to send binary files through electronic mail.

standard.title: Web Services Business Process Execution Language (WSBPEL) version 2.0

standardrecord.applicability: WS-BPEL provides a language for the specification of Executable and Abstract business processes. By doing so, it extends the Web Services interaction model and enables it to support business transactions. Note: the final version have bben approved, and will be released shortly.

standard.title: W3C Web Service Choreography Interface version 1.0

standardrecord.applicability: WSCI is a Web service orchestration and choreography spec defined by the BPMI (Business Process Management Initiative) corporation. Note that the WSCI specification is one of the primary inputs into the W3C's Web Services Choreography Working Group which published a Candidate Recommendation on WS-DSL version 1.0 on November 2005 to replace WSCI.

standard.title: BPML Business Process Model and Notation version 2.0:2010

standardrecord.applicability: BPML is "a meta-language for the modeling of business processes. BPML provides an abstracted execution model for collaborative and transactional business processes that span multiple applications and business partners, behind the firewall and over the Internet,across multiple verticals." BMPN provide a notation that is readily understandable by all business users, from the business analysts that create the initial drafts of the processes, to the technical developers responsible for implementing the technology that will perform those processes, and finally, to the business people who will manage and monitor those processes.

standard.title: Open Services Infrastructure (OpenSiS) version 1.9.5.6

standardrecord.applicability: OpenSIS is a service oriented approach to system integration. The concept is based on usage of so called connectors that adapts heterogeneous systems to a well defined service interaction layer. The services are described using SDL (which is a subset of OMG IDL and not to be confused with Specification and Description Language). The connectors then offer uniform communication between services, a discovery mechanism through a service directory and authentication of service consumers.

standard.title: JavaTM 2 Platform, Enterprise Edition 1.4 (JAVA EE v.6:2009) Specification ed. 1.5.0:2004

standardrecord.applicability: Java Platform, Enterprise Edition (Java EE) is the industry standard for developing portable, robust, scalable and secure server-side Java applications.

standard.title: Java Remote Method Invocation

standardrecord.applicability: The Java platform's remote method invocation system has been specifically designed to operate in the Java application environment. The Java programming language's RMI system assumes the homogeneous environment of the Java virtual machine (JVM), and the system can therefore take advantage of the Java platform's object model whenever possible.

standard.title: Java Business Integration

standardrecord.applicability: JBI defines the core of a service oriented integration bus and component architecture for SOA. It standardizes the common message routing architecture, plug-in interfaces for service engines and bindings, and a mechanism to combine multiple services into a single executable and auditable unit of work.

standard.title: Microsoft .NET

standardrecord.applicability: Microsoft .NET framework is a Microsoft product closely related to application development for the Windows platform. The framework includes the closely related C# programming language (even if it is a formal ISO standard) and the Common Language Runtime (CLR), which simplified is Microsoft's response to JAVA. Programs written for the .NET framework execute in CLR which provides the appearance of an application virtual machine, so that programmers need not consider the capabilities of the specific CPU that will execute the program. The framework also includes libraries for development of web service applications.

standard.title: Jini

standardrecord.applicability: Jini network technology is an open architecture that enables developers to create network-centric services that are highly adaptive to change. An architecture based on the idea of a federation rather than central control, Jini technology can be used to build adaptive networks that are scalable, evolvable and flexible as typically required in dynamic computing environments. Jini technology provides a flexible infrastructure for delivering services in a network and for creating spontaneous interactions between clients that use these services regardless of their hardware or software implementations.

standard.title: Web Services Distributed Management: Management Using Web Services (MUWS 1.1) Part 1
Web Services Distributed Management: Management Using Web Services (MUWS 1.1) Part 2
Web Services Distributed Management: Management of Web Services (WSDM-MOWS) 1.1

profilerecord.applicability: Web Services Distributed Management (WSDM) is an OASIS standard that specifies infrastructure support for the integration of web service management aspects across heterogeneous systems. This is done through management specific messaging via web services.

standard.title: UDDI Version 2.04 API Specification
UDDI Version 2.03, Data Structure Reference
UDDI Version 2 XML Schema
UDDI Version 2.03, Replication Specification
UDDI Version 2.03 XML Replication Schema
UDDI Version 2 XML Custody Schema
UDDI Version 2.01, Operator's Specification

profilerecord.applicability:
These documents
describe the programming interface that is exposed by all instances of the Universal Description, Discovery and Integration (UDDI)
outline the details of each of the XML structures associated with these messages. The UDDI Programmers API Specification defines approximately 30 SOAP messages that are used to perform inquiry and publishing functions against any UDDI compliant service registry.
describe the UDDI Data Structure Reference (preceding)
describe the data replication process and programmatic interface required to achieve complete data replication between UDDI Operators
describe the behavior and operational parameters required of the UDDI Node Operators.
registry, .

standard.title: Universal Description Discovery & Integration (UDDI)

standardrecord.applicability:
Web services are meaningful only if potential users may find information sufficient to permit their execution. The focus of UDDI is the definition of a set of services supporting the description and discovery of (1) business, organizations, and other Web service providers, (2) the Web services they make available, and (3) the technical interfaces which may be used to access those services. Based on a commom set of industry standards, including HTTP, XML, XML Schema, and SOAP, UDDI provides an interoperable, foundational infrastructure for a Web services-based software environment for both publicly available services and services only exposed internally within an oranization. This document describes the Web services and behaviours of all instances of a UDDI registry.
Should not be used in a secure environment.

standard.title: ebXML Registry Information Model Version 3.0

standardrecord.applicability: An ebXML Registry is an information system that securely manages any content type and the standardized metadata that describes it. The ebXML Registry provides a set of services that enable sharing of content and metadata between organizational entities in a federated environment. This document defines the types of metadata and content that can be stored in an ebXML Registry.

standard.title: TIDE Information Discovery (Request-Response) Protocol v2.2

standardrecord.applicability: The TIDE Information Discovery concept evolved out of the requirement to discover, extract, and make useful, information from emerging and legacy systems. The Information Discovery Protocols contribute to these goals by combining existing technologies in a new way. But this is not enough. To achieve the desired effect numerous systems must implement the Information Discovery Protocol (a standard). To support this goal the protocol is designed to be small and easy to implement and scalable. This approach reduces the implementation cost and increases the probability of adoption by legacy systems. The TIDE Information Discovery Request-Response Protocol takes the concepts implements the general Information Discovery concept as a web service.

standard.title: TIDE Information Discovery (Subscribe-Publish) Protocol v2.2:2009

standardrecord.applicability: The main objective of the Subscribe-Publish Protocol is to provide a means of getting asychronous information from a TIDE Producer without the Consumer having to request in a synchronous way every now and then. This way, the Consumer will be provided with the information as it is available. Another important aspect is that the Service Consumer can submit an RDF-based query by example in order to constrain the subscription so only information that matches such a constraint will be delivered by the Producer.

standard.title: Web Service Description Language (WSDL) 1.1

standardrecord.applicability: WSDL is an XML format for describing network services as a set of endpoints operating on messages containing either document-oriented or procedure-oriented information. The operations and messages are desribed abstractly, and then bound to a concrete network protocol and message format to define an endpoint. Related concrete endpoints are combined into abstract endpoints (services). WSDL is extensible to allow description of endpoints and their messages regardless of what message formats or network protocols are used to communicate, however, the only bindings described in this document describe how to use WSDL in conjunction with SOAP 1.1, HTTP GET/POST and MIME.

standard.title: XML Path Language 1.0

standardrecord.applicability: XPath is a language for addressing parts of an XML document, designed to be used by both XSLT and XPointer.

standard.title: Web Services Profile 1

standardrecord.applicability:
Since SOAP 1.1 was released in April, 2000, there has been tremendous industry uptake in the basic specifications that constitute Web services as we know them today. SOAP 1.2, WSDL 1.1, and UDDI 2.0 are the latest specifications that are used to describe, publish, enable discovery, and invoke Web Services. Each of these specifications is based on XML and, in particular, XML Schema. Given this small set of specifications, it is not hard to keep track of products and their degree of support for the specifications.
Through the first phase of Web services adoption, four specifications have risen to prominence as providing the basic functionality required to start developing Web services. These specifications are XML Schema 1.0, SOAP 1.1, WSDL 1.1, and UDDI 2.0. The first profile proposed is WS-I Basic Web services
WS-I Basic:
XML Schema 1.0
SOAP 1.1
WSDL 1.1
UDDI 2.0

standard.title: Semantics of Business Vocabulary and Business Rules

standardrecord.applicability: The Semantics of Business Vocabulary and Business Rules (SBVR) is an adopted standard of the Object Management Group (OMG) intended to be the basis for formal and detailed natural language declarative description of a complex entity, such as a business. SBVR is intended to formalize complex compliance rules, such as operational rules for an enterprise, security policy, standard compliance, or regulatory compliance rules. Such formal vocabularies and rules can be interpreted and used by computer systems. SBVR is an integral part of the OMG?s Model Driven Architecture (MDA).

standard.title: Windows 32-Bit Application Programming Interfaces

standardrecord.applicability: The Microsoft Windows application programming interface (API) provides building blocks used by applications written for Microsoft Windows, including Windows .NET Server, Windows XP, Windows 2003 Server, Windows 2000, Windows NT, Windows 95, Windows 98, and Windows Millennium Edition (Windows Me). It provides an application with a graphical user interface, display graphics and formatted text, and manage system objects such as memory, files, and processes.

standard.title: X Window System, Version 11, release 5.5

standardrecord.applicability: X Window System 11 Release 5 is a graphical user interface that attempts modularize device dependence and device independence so that applications (clients) can run on a number of devices from a number of different vendors and the X server takes care of rendering what the application wishes to display. This is the mit source distribution for X11R5.

standard.title: X Window System, Version 11, release 7.5:2009

standardrecord.applicability: The X Window System is the de-facto standard for GUI in the Open Systems Environment. Its software, written in C, has proven to be highly portable between various hardware platforms and operating systems. specifications for user interface services

standard.title: X/Open Common Desktop Environment (XCDE), V1.0
CDE Definitions and Infrastructure
CDE Services and Applications
CDE Calendering and Scheduling API (XCS)
X/Open Motif Toolkit API
X/Open X Window (X11R5) System

standardrecord.applicability: The Common Desktop Environment (CDE) is an integrated graphical user interface for open systems desktop computing. It delivers a single, standard graphical interface for the management of data and files (the graphical desktop) and applications. CDE's primary benefits -- deriving from ease-of-use, consistency, configurabbility, portabiility, distributed design, and protection of investment in today's applications -- make open systems desktop computers as easy to use as PCs, but with the added power of local and network resources available at the click of a mouse.

standard.title: DoD Human Computer Interface (HCI) Style Guide, DoD TAFIM Volume 8, V3.0

standardrecord.applicability: This guide provides a common framework for HCI design and implementation. It defines and documents the long-term functional goals, objectives, and requirements of the human computer interface. Interface implementation options are standardised enabling all DoD applications to appear and operate in a reasonably consistent manner

standard.title: Motif Style Guide 1.2

standardrecord.applicability: It describes how an application should interact with the user. Guidelines for application programming, new widget development, and customization and extensions are provided. The purpose of this guide is to explain how to create OSF/Motif compliant applications, window managers, controls, and systems

standard.title: CDE 2.1/Motif Release 2.1:1997.

standardrecord.applicability:
The Motif user interface was developed for applications running on any system which can support the X Window System. Motif 2.1 includes the following components:
Toolkit
Style Guide
Window Manager
User Interface Language (UIL)
The OSF/Motif Toolkit is described below in the toolkit section.

standard.title: The Windows Interface Guidelines for Software Design

standardrecord.applicability: This is an essential handbook for all programmers and designers working with the latest release of Windows, regardless of experience level or development tools used. This book covers the basic principles of user interface design and design methodologies and specifies how data-centered concepts such as objects and properties can be applied to interface design. It includes detailed information on mouse, keyboard, and pen interaction and on how to use the common interface elements supplied by the system. You'll also find information about special considerations such as network computing, international users, and users with disabilities.

standard.title: MOD (UK) Defence Technical Architecture, Issue 2

standardrecord.applicability: This style guide is designed to provide specific guidance on the presentation and use of Microsoft Graphical User Interface (GUI) when developing software systems using Microsoft Windows within the context of the UK Defence Technical Architecture. The guide identifies the MS Windows user interface components that are to be used when developing MS Windows applications in the UK MOD. It provides descriptive notes on each component and guidelines on how, when and when not to use each component. It is intended for use for designers and developers of application program modules where they use MS Windows user interface components as well as system integrators developing the system level user interface.

standard.title: X/Open Curses, Issue 4, Version 2

standardrecord.applicability: The CURSES functions provide a terminal-independent method of updating character screens

standard.title: NATO friendly Force Information Standard for Interoperability of Force Tracking Systems
RFID Data protocol: application interface
RFID Data protocol: data encoding rules and logical memory functions
Supply chain applications of RFID -- Freight containers

standardrecord.applicability:
ISO 17363:2007 defines the usage of read/write radio-frequency identification technology (RFID) cargo shipment-specific tags on freight containers for supply chain management purposes (shipment tags). It defines the air-interface communications, a common set of required data structures, and a commonly organized set of optional data requirements (through common syntax and semantics).
It contains recommendations about a containerized cargo supply chain RFID system, based on shipment tags; specific recommendations about mandatory non-reprogrammable information on the shipment tag; and specific recommendations about optional, re-programmable information on the shipment tag.
Identified within ISO 17363:2007 are the air-interface and communication parameters for active radio-frequency identification communications using ISO/IEC 18000-7.
ISO 17363:2007 is applicable to freight containers as defined in ISO 668 and to freight containers that are not defined by other ISO standards. It complements ISO 10374 for permanent container license-plate tags.
It fully describes cargo shipment-specific tags.
It does not address smart container technologies affixed to, or inside, freight containers (e.g. sensors) for supply chain management purposes.

standard.title: Supply chain applications of RFID -- Returnable transport items (RTIs)

standardrecord.applicability:
ISO 17364:2009 defines the basic features of RFID for the use in the supply chain when applied to returnable transport items. In particular it:
provides specifications for the identification of the RTI,
makes recommendations about additional information on the RF tag,
specifies the semantics and data syntax to be used,
specifies the data protocol to be used to interface with business applications and the RFID system,
specifies the minimum performance requirements,
specifies the air interface standards between the RF interrogator and RF tag, and
specifies the reuse and recyclability of the RF tag.

standard.title: Supply chain applications of RFID -- Transport units

standardrecord.applicability:
ISO 17365:2009 defines the basic features of RFID for the use in the supply chain when applied to transport units. In particular it:
provides specifications for the identification of the transport unit,
makes recommendations about additional information on the RF tag,
specifies the semantics and data syntax to be used,
specifies the data protocol to be used to interface with business applications and the RFID system,
specifies the minimum performance requirements,
specifies the air interface standards between the RF interrogator and RF tag, and
specifies the reuse and recyclability of the RF tag.

standard.title: Supply chain applications of RFID -- Product packaging

standardrecord.applicability: TBD

standard.title: Supply chain applications of RFID -- Product tagging

standardrecord.applicability:
ISO 17367:2009 defines the basic features of RFID for the use in the supply chain when applied to product tagging. In particular it:
provides specific recommendations about the encoded identification of the product,
makes recommendations about additional information about the product on the RF tag,
makes recommendations about the semantics and data syntax to be used,
makes recommendations about the data protocol to be used to interface with business applications and the RFID system, and
makes recommendations about the air interface standards between the RF interrogator and RF tag.

standard.title: The Open Applications Group Integration Specification
Product life cycle support and application modules

standardrecord.applicability: This standard that specifies an information model that defines what information can be exchanged and represented to support a product through life. This definition is provided by using the EXPRESS information modelling language. The basic data structures that are exchanged are defined by EXPRESS Entities. For example in PLCS there are entities defining Parts, versions of parts (Part_versions) and people (Person). Each entity may have attributes that provide further information about the thing being represented by an entity. For example, a person has a first name and last name. These are attributes of a Person.

standard.title: International Specification for Technical Publications:2008

standardrecord.applicability: S1000D covers the planning and management, production, exchange, distribution and use of technical documentation that support the life cycle of any civil or military project. Projects include air, land and sea vehicles or equipments.

standard.title: NATO Policy for Systems Life Cycle Management

orgkey.text: AeroSpace and Defence Industries Association of Europe
